webTitle: McCarthy restores Irish expectations

fields.headline: Green machine is back
fields.standfirst: "I can enjoy the next few months off, not having to listen to any of the bullshit I've had to listen to the last couple of months." The criticism may have got to Mick McCarthy but he has ridden the storm with aplomb
fields.trailText: Mick McCarthy has ridden a storm of criticism with aplomb, says Ian Whittell.
fields.body:
The palm reader on Dublin's Grafton Street was doing brisk business this week, thanks to the late summer tourist traffic and garrulous foreign exchange students. What a shame Mick McCarthy was not available for a reading.

For the first time since Jack Charlton's unique brand of football mysticism expired after the 1994 World Cup Finals, the Irish national team are once more experiencing boom times and an air of unrestrained expectation, due almost entirely to McCarthy's managerial skills.

'For the first time in a long time, expectations are high again,' said goalkeeper Alan Kelly after Ireland had beaten Estonia 2-0 at Lansdowne Road on Wednesday, building on hugely impressive draws in Holland and Portugal that opened their World Cup qualifying campaign.

'We went for a walk on the morning of the game and people are coming up to you on the street, wishing you luck, saying they expect you to win. 'That creates a bit more pressure but that's good. People's reactions are telling you we're heading in the right direction. We want people to be enthusiastic about us; makes us feel good, makes the country feel good.'

It would presumably take the most gifted palm reader to predict whether Ireland's start to their Group 2 schedule will result in qualification for the 2002 Finals. After all, only the group winner is assured a place and achieving that goal in a group containing two of Europe's elite nations would easily rank with anything McCarthy's predecessor accomplished during his tenure.

The contrast with England's current travails, and those that befell McCarthy's fellow Yorkshireman Kevin Keegan last weekend, could not be more emphatic.

McCarthy has taken a team that could reasonably be said to include two world-class players - both called Keane - able Premiership performers in Kevin Kilbane, Mark Kinsella, Ian Harte, Stephen Carr and 34-year-old Niall Quinn, and moulded them with Premier League reserves and first division journeymen to create a formidable team. Estonian coach Tarmo Ruutli rates them genuine rivals to Portugal for first place.

It is a remarkable achievement, given Ireland's population - 3.5 million - and the fact that a total of one silver medal in the Sydney Olympics suggests that the country, for whatever demographic or social reasons, is not producing many world-class athletes in any sport.

Perhaps that paucity of resources is, conversely, one of Ireland's strengths. McCarthy has named the same line-up for all three qualifying games to date, a recurring theme when the team's impressive start was analysed this week.

'To know you are Ireland's centre-half or full-back, at the age of the likes of Richard Dunne, is a great achievement and must do wonders for confidence,' said Kelly. 'Continuity doesn't breed complacency, it breeds confidence.'

And confidence, naturally, seeps down from above. It is a quality McCarthy possesses in abundance and which is spreading throughout the Irish team once more.

However, it would be wrong to simply view Irish football in the new millennium as a Roddy Doyle novel in waiting - partly folk ritual, partly a nation's rites of passage.

The Ireland of 2000 is very different to the country that fell in love with the team when Charlton took them to success in their first major tournament, the 1988 European Championships.

The country, Dublin in particular, is growing, experiencing an economic upturn that has raised national self-esteem and expectation. Six years of unprecedented glory under Charlton were just part of that phenomenon.

It helped explain why McCarthy received such a harsh press after failing, in play-offs, to reach the last World Cup and Euro 2000, results that - pre-Charlton - would have been considered moral triumphs.

There was even an active 'McCarthy out' movement following the latter loss to Turkey, a movement in no small part egged on in the Irish media through the country's premier man of sporting letters, Eamonn Dunphy, whose notorious feud with Charlton has carried over into criticism of his successor and 'disciple' McCarthy.

But, unlike Keegan, McCarthy refuses to allow such opinion to affect him or, importantly, his work. 'I think the phrase is, "I've got a neck like a jockey's bollocks",' he explained this week.

'As a player I needed a thick skin and as a manager I've needed it more. I've never met anybody who likes criticism but what experience tells you is you musn't let it change what you want to do.

'I'm still here after nearly five years. If I'd gone after the last campaign someone would no doubt have come in and done it completely differently, changed the personnel and approach. We would have lost that continuity.

'But I never considered walking out, I knew the players supported me and most of the general public supported me.'

It would be wrong to assume that McCarthy is unaffected by his continuing feud with numerous sections of the Irish media, however, as his opening comments in the post-Estonia press conference testified.

Q. 'Will you enjoy your few months off now?'

A. 'Yes, I can enjoy the next few months off, not having to listen to any of the bullshit I've had to listen to the last couple of months.'

Yet his unerring belief in his managerial ability outweighs the risk of criticism affecting his work - 'I'm not looking for vindication from the people that criticise me,' he had said in Lisbon eight days ago. 'I do what I do, I personally think I'm good at it, no matter what anybody else thinks.'

No less an authority than Louis Van Gaal agreed in September, pointing out the Irish had outpassed and outplayed the Dutch for 70 minutes en route to a 2-2 draw.

It should also be noted that the first Irish goal against Estonia came at the end of a 13-pass move while one of 19 almost brought a goal for Robbie Keane. McCarthy may have restored Irish football credibility but he has decidedly not done it by Charlton's long ball mantra.

'We're getting the Green Machine back on the road again,' said McCarthy. 'Looking at the crowds, feeling the atmosphere around the place. It's great.'

webTitle: Power list reflects business on the rise

fields.headline: Power list reflects business on the rise
fields.standfirst: Winners and losers
fields.trailText: Winners and losers...
fields.body:
Power can prove short-lived. Currency dealer George Soros, model Naomi Campbell and former British Airways boss Bob Ayling are among those who have dropped out of the latest Observer/Channel 4 Power List. Four of the five highest new entries are businessmen.

For the third year running, an expert panel has selected people according to their capacity to 'influence the quality of people's lives, lifestyles and values in Britain today'. Tony Blair is first and Gordon Brown is second.

Six of the other top 10 work in banking or commerce. Steve Case, chairman of AOL Time Warner, has leapt from 59th place last year to fourth, a recognition of his new company's huge power over the world internet business.

Will Hutton, chairman of the Power List panel, said: 'We simply concentrated on the actual influence that people had on our lives in the year 2000. Sometimes that can be ephemeral, sometimes it is longer lasting. Many figures are, inevitably, international.

'We did seriously discuss whether Gordon Brown deserved the No 1 slot. He is the animating intellectual, economic and political force behind New Labour.' Thirty-eight of the top 100 entries now represent national or international businesses. Just one, the Pearson chief executive Marjorie Scardino, is a woman. The Microsoft founder Bill Gates is No 8, Rupert Murdoch is ninth and Sir John Browne, the BP chairman who some accused of helping to orchestrate the fuel crisis, is at No 10.

US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan is at No 3 and President Bill Clinton is seventh. Wim Duisenburg, president of the European Central Bank, is at No 28. The BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland disappears from this year's list altogether. Although he was at 71 last year, his influence has waned as he becomes overshadowed by new Director-General Greg Dyke, who is now at 16. Martin McGuinness and Chris Patten, who both played parts in the Northern Ireland peace process, have left the list.

Mr and Mrs David Beckham consolidate their position (59) as the most influential entertainers listed, one place above Prince Charles. However, the disappearance this year of Elton John, Rory Bremner, Naomi Campbell, Ewan MacGregor and Sir Melvyn Bragg will remind them that their power will only last as long as their singing and footballing skills can be sustained.

Former Chancellor Kenneth Clarke, who four years ago was almost as influential as Gordon Brown is today, has dropped out of the Power List altogether as the possibility of his one day leading a moderate Tory party has dissipated. William Hague has risen to 50, from 228, a reflection of the Government's recent uncertain footing. What is remarkable also is that there is only one black or Asian British entry among the 300. This revelation comes a week after the Commission on the Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain warned that ethnic minorities still face widespread prejudice at work.

The sole black entry this year is of the DJs Dreem Team, who are at No 211 in recognition of their huge influence on the music industry and youth tastes. However, as with most entertainers, their presence is likely to be short-lived.

All the other minority ethnic figures in the 2000 Power List are from abroad. They include UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and former South African President Nelson Mandela, who figure in positions 78 and 195.

Lord Parekh, chairman of the commission, said yesterday: 'Sadly, the criteria for selection for the Power List appear to have been correctly applied. In the last half century, black and Asian people have moved from the bottom rung of the hierarchy but their absence in top positions is still very striking.

'It's only when people are at the top in various fields that that are able to shape organisational culture and help others. As a country, we need to take this issue much more seriously than we have done in the past.'

Panel member Tamara Ingram, chief executive of advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi, said: 'That there are not many people from diverse backgrounds indicates that the new order in Great Britain is still the old order.'

The Power List was selected by a team of seven. Hutton and Ingram were joined by biologist Lewis Wolpert, former Downing Street adviser Lord Powell, style adviser Peter York, Rachel Newsome, editor of cult magazine Dazed & Confused, and Heather Rabbatts, former chief executive of Lambeth council.

Almost 1,000 individuals were rated by each panellist on the basis of their influence on government, culture, the media and business. Highest scorers were those such as the Prime Minister or Murdoch, who are influential in more than one field.

The number of women on this year's list is only 40. This is 13 per cent of the total - up from 11 per cent last year and 9 per cent in 1998. Apart from Scardino and Victoria Beckham, the only other women in the top 100 are Cherie Booth, the Queen, News of the World editor Rebekah Wade and Madonna.

webTitle: Who holds the reins of power in Britain? Part 2

fields.headline: Who holds the reins of power in Britain? Part 2
fields.standfirst: In this special    report we reveal the names that count
fields.trailText: In this special report we reveal the names that count...
fields.body:
40
Lord Harry Woolf of Barnes, QC Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales (79).

In June he became the most senior judge in England and Wales.

41
Professor Liam Donaldson Chief Medical Officer (85).

The government's most senior medical adviser. Co-wrote report on GM foods.

42
Sir John Bond Chairman, HSBC Holdings (194).

Has built one of the great international banks. Chose to waive his pounds 260,000 salary.

43
Lord Dennis Stevenson of Coddenham CBE Chairman, Pearson; Chairman, Halifax; Chairman, House of Lords Appointments Commission (24).

Pearson owns the FT, Pearson TV and Penguin books. Stevenson undertook an IT study in schools for Tony Blair with pounds 100,000 of his own money and then advised on implementation.

44
Lord Richard Rogers of Riverside Architect (65).

Designed The Lloyds Building, Pompidou Centre, Millennium Dome. Chairs government's urban taskforce to find innovations in housing on developed land.

45
Sir Richard Evans Chairman, British Aerospace (56).

Head of the UK's largest export earner earns pounds 674,000 a year. Key player in many of the more substantial arms deals.

46
David Miliband Head of No10 Policy Unit (29).

A member of New Labour's inner circle, Miliband and his unit are there to fine-tune Blair's political strategy. Has helped shape policy on issues like welfare reform and education, and the Third Way.

47
Dr Derek Morris Chairman, Competition Commission (formerly Monopolies and Mergers Commission) (128).

Appointed head of competition watchdog last year, of which (as MMC) he has been a member since 1991.

48
Cherie Booth QC Lawyer; PM's wife (73).

Speaks out on wide range of issues in course of her legal career. Specialising in employment law, Booth has taken on some high-profile cases including the lesbian rights case against South West Trains. Her pregnancy raised the profile of older mothers and set the agenda on paternity leave - on which she's also tackled the government in court.

49
Alan Milburn Health Secretary (86).

Launched a 10-year programme to cut heart disease and stroke by 40 per cent, pledging to end the lottery of cardiac care and save 20,000 lives a year.

50
Rt Hon William Hague MP Leader of the Opposition; Leader, Conservative and Unionist Party (228).

Reinvented as populist and right wing, making provocative statements, with policies proposing illegal immigrants be held in detention camps. Supported rights of homeowners to defend their property in the wake of the Tony Martin case. Has pledged to award a 5-10 increase in basic pension on top of anything Brown delivers. Such policies are winning some favour with floating voters and former Labour supporters.

51
Sir Howard Davies Chairman, Financial Services Authority (80).

Former adviser to Nigel Lawson at Treasury, head of the CBI and deputy governor of the Bank of England.

52
Vladimir Putin President of Russia (NEW).

Yeltsin's successor, a former KGB spy, has sworn to unite Russia. This has been interpreted by some as a veiled threat to rebels, notably in Chechnya, where war rages on.

53
Michael Jackson Chief Executive, Channel Four (201).

Channel 4's youngest chief. Secured cricket rights from the BBC. Planning to launch more cable - general entertainment, betting and education channels, gay and lesbian website. Latest audience figures up.

54
Sir Peter Davis Chief Executive, J. Sainsbury (NEW).

Succeeded Dino Adriano as new broom. Only two weeks after his arrival, a boardroom shuffle stamped the mark of his authority on the ailing supermarket business, that included the removal of Deputy Chief Executive, David Bremner.

55

Sir George Mathewson Group Chief Executive, Royal Bank of Scotland Group (NEW).

The bank has sharply increased profits during his tenure, and acquired NatWest after a takeover battle with Bank of Scotland.

56
Charles Allen Chairman, Granada Media (NEW).

He presided over a rise in profits from pounds 480m to pounds 835m since 1996. During his reign Granada also completed pounds 730m takeover of LWT, and pounds 3.2bn hostile takeover of Forte.

57
Alan Rusbridger Editor, the Guardian (95).

The Guardian won National Newspaper of the Year in 1999. The newspaper remains in Rusbridger's own words 'a radical irritant to the Government.'

58
Hans Snook Chief Executive, Orange (NEW).

In May took charge of Europe's second-largest mobile-phone group with a likely market capitalisation of pounds 92bn.

59
David and Victoria Beckham Manchester United and England footballer, married to entertainer Posh Spice (69).

Beckham came joint top in a Sports Council poll asking young people which sports stars they most admired. His wife is one of Britain's richest young women, and the most photographed celebrity in Britain.

60
HRH Prince Charles Windsor Prince of Wales; Heir to the throne; Duke of Cornwall (14).

Prince's Trust is biggest charity of its type in Britain, and biggest single provider for the voluntary option in New Deal under which he announced pounds 50m investment scheme to create 30,000 new businesses over five years. Accused of politicising the monarchy, got Downing Street's back up with a succession of anti-GM statements.

61
Jacques Chirac President, France (18).

Key European figure, though last year his presidency was jeopardised by allegations of corruption during his time as mayor of Paris.

62
Sir Brian Pitman Chairman, Lloyds TSB Group; Chairman, Next (166).

Pitman engineered Lloyds' take-over of Cheltenham and Gloucester Building Society in 1995. The following year he moved up to become chairman. Lloyds TSB is the second largest internet banking operator in the UK with 250,000 customers. Next Directory is 2 per cent ahead in profits from last year.

63
Lord Norman Foster of Thames Bank Architect (132) . Designed Stansted airport, Millennium Bridge, Cambridge Law Library, Sainsbury Centre, UEA, and is designing pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square.

64
Sir Nicholas Serota Director, Tate Gallery; Chair, Turner Prize (99).

It is his vision that made Tate Britain and Tate Modern - the biggest modern art gallery in the world - the hottest tickets in town.

65
Zhu Rong-ji Chinese Premier (82).

Chinese state newspapers compared Nato to Nazi Germany over attacks on Yugoslavia and the Chinese embassy. Zhu is an economic reformer renowned for his plain speaking and short temper.

66
David Trimble First Minister, Northern Ireland Assembly; Leader, Ulster Unionist Party (21).

Under severe pressure within his party from those who feel that the republicans have failed to honour decommissioning targets.If his position is undermined by his own party, the peace process might be fatally wounded.

67
Chris Woodhead HM Chief Inspector of Schools (64).

Has become a controversial focus of anti-liberal reaction to the 'child-centred' teaching methods of the postwar period. His influence on education policy is great.

68
Larry Ellison Chairman and CEO, Oracle (NEW).

As the Information Age gives way to the Internet Age, Silicon Valley's bad boy gets revenge: database software is now the rage. Oracle's database sales surged 32%after previous sluggish growth.

69
Mario Monti Competition Commissioner, European Commission (NEW).

Under the authority of Monti, the mission of Competition Directorate General is to establish and implement a coherent policy for the EU.

70
Sir Richard Wilson Cabinet Secretary and Head of the Civil Service (30).

Wilson reports directly to Blair and runs the Home Civil Service.

71
Rebekah Wade Editor, News of the World (NEW)

Last May Wade replaced Phil Hall and became Britain's youngest national newspaper editor. Uneasy start with 'name and shame' paedophile campaign.

72
Dr Andy Grove Chairman, Intel Corporation (41).

The world's biggest computer-chip maker. In May Intel became the world's biggest company by stock-market value, skipping ahead of Microsoft and Cisco Systems.

73
Steven Spielberg Film Director and Producer; Founder, DreamWorks SKG (49).

Spielberg is the most successful popular film-maker of all time, saving Hollywood with new standards for innovative direction and special effects.

74
HM Queen Elizabeth Windsor Monarch (51).

Meets the PM every week. Met Camilla Parker Bowles at a Highgrove party, causing media flurry.

75
Tim Berners-Lee Director, World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) (81).

Conceived the WWW in 1989 as a model of simple access and sharing information via his invention of HTML. Now director of the W3 Consortium, devoting its energies to the privacy problem.

76
Anji Hunter Special Assistant to the Prime Minister (58).

Protector and friend of Blair since schooldays. Guards access to his office.

77
Gerry Adams MP President, Sinn Fein (20).

Key player in Northern Ireland peace process. Announced Sinn Fein was committed to peaceful and democratic means to make progress.

78
Kofi Annan Secretary General, United Nations (16).

A formidable diplomat, Annan reinvigorated the UN after his appointment in 1996.

79
Stelios Haji-Ioannou Chairman, easyGroup (185).

Son of a Greek shipping magnate, founded the Luton-based no-frills airline in 1995. Now worth £187m. Moving into the world of cybercafes with the launch of easyEverything.

80
Jean-Marie Messier Chief Executive, Vivendi (NEW).

VivendiNet (a joint venture between Vivendi and Canal+) and Vodafone joined forces to create Vizzavi, a multi-access internet portal that will allow customers to access personalised services such as email, address book and calendar - all via their mobile phone.

81
Professor Sir John Krebs Director, Food Standards Agency (NEW).

Launched in April to provide the public with independent information and advice about food safety and standards, the agency's remit is to take an overall view across the industry from farm to fork.

82
Niall FitzGerald Chairman, Unilever (100).

The newest thing the detergent industry has to a visionary has been reiterating his company's commitment to emerging markets and berating the industry for treating water and chemicals as inexhaustible resources. Sponsored the Louise Bourgeois sculptures in Tate Modern.

83
John Vickers Director General, Office of Fair Trading (NEW).

The new consumers' champion, the 42-year-old former Bank of England Chief Economist will be expected to bring an end to 'Rip-off Britain'.

84
Ken Livingstone Mayor of London (NEW).

The first democratically elected mayor. Quiet start, though recent appointment of Robert Kiley as 'Tube czar' may signal the start of his tenure proper.

85
Rt Hon Michael Portillo MP Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer (195).

The 'Look, I have no lectern' speech at the Tory conference was praised and critiqued in equal measure. Likely challenger to Hague as future Tory leader.

86
Baroness Helena Kennedy of The Shaws QC Chairman, British Council; Chancellor, Oxford Brookes University (165).

First woman to be appointed chair of the British Council. Close friend of the Blairs, produced the Kennedy Report on Education.

87
Don Cruickshank Chairman, London Stock Exchange (285).

Former Oftel regulator and Chairman of Action 2000 . The tormentor of the UK banks replaces Sir John Kemp-Welch as new chairman of London Stock Exchange.

88
Professor Mike Richards National Cancer Director (cancer czar) (NEW).

Former head of breast cancer research at Guy's Hospital. Will be implementing a two-week waiting time standard for all cancers.

89
Dr Thomas Michael (Mike) Dexter Director, Wellcome Trust (116).

Commands a research budget of pounds 250m. Cancer biologist and not afraid to criticise the system. He was the first to discover, among other things how to grow stem cells in vitro.

90
Ian Davies Managing Director, McKinsey & Co Inc UK (227).

Heads London office of international management consultancy.

 Click here to read numbers 91-138

In June he became the most senior judge in England and Wales. 41 Professor Liam Donaldson Chief Medical Officer (85). The government's most senior medical adviser. Co-wrote report on GM foods. 42 Sir John Bond Chairman, HSBC Holdings (194). Has built one of the great international banks. Chose to waive his pounds 260,000 salary. 43 Lord Dennis Stevenson of Coddenham CBE Chairman, Pearson; Chairman, Halifax; Chairman, House of Lords Appointments Commission (24). Pearson owns the FT, Pearson TV and Penguin books. Stevenson undertook an IT study in schools for Tony Blair with pounds 100,000 of his own money and then advised on implementation. 44 Lord Richard Rogers of Riverside Architect (65). Designed The Lloyds Building, Pompidou Centre, Millennium Dome. Chairs government's urban taskforce to find innovations in housing on developed land. 45 Sir Richard Evans Chairman, British Aerospace (56). Head of the UK's largest export earner earns pounds 674,000 a year. Key player in many of the more substantial arms deals. 46 David Miliband Head of No10 Policy Unit (29). A member of New Labour's inner circle, Miliband and his unit are there to fine-tune Blair's political strategy. Has helped shape policy on issues like welfare reform and education, and the Third Way. 47 Dr Derek Morris Chairman, Competition Commission (formerly Monopolies and Mergers Commission) (128). Appointed head of competition watchdog last year, of which (as MMC) he has been a member since 1991. 48 Cherie Booth QC Lawyer; PM's wife (73). Speaks out on wide range of issues in course of her legal career. Specialising in employment law, Booth has taken on some high-profile cases including the lesbian rights case against South West Trains. Her pregnancy raised the profile of older mothers and set the agenda on paternity leave - on which she's also tackled the government in court. 49 Alan Milburn Health Secretary (86). Launched a 10-year programme to cut heart disease and stroke by 40 per cent, pledging to end the lottery of cardiac care and save 20,000 lives a year. 50 Rt Hon William Hague MP Leader of the Opposition; Leader, Conservative and Unionist Party (228). Reinvented as populist and right wing, making provocative statements, with policies proposing illegal immigrants be held in detention camps. Supported rights of homeowners to defend their property in the wake of the Tony Martin case. Has pledged to award a 5-10 increase in basic pension on top of anything Brown delivers. Such policies are winning some favour with floating voters and former Labour supporters. 51 Sir Howard Davies Chairman, Financial Services Authority (80). Former adviser to Nigel Lawson at Treasury, head of the CBI and deputy governor of the Bank of England. 52 Vladimir Putin President of Russia (NEW). Yeltsin's successor, a former KGB spy, has sworn to unite Russia. This has been interpreted by some as a veiled threat to rebels, notably in Chechnya, where war rages on. 53 Michael Jackson Chief Executive, Channel Four (201). Channel 4's youngest chief. Secured cricket rights from the BBC. Planning to launch more cable - general entertainment, betting and education channels, gay and lesbian website. Latest audience figures up. 54 Sir Peter Davis Chief Executive, J. Sainsbury (NEW). Succeeded Dino Adriano as new broom. Only two weeks after his arrival, a boardroom shuffle stamped the mark of his authority on the ailing supermarket business, that included the removal of Deputy Chief Executive, David Bremner. 55 Sir George Mathewson Group Chief Executive, Royal Bank of Scotland Group (NEW). The bank has sharply increased profits during his tenure, and acquired NatWest after a takeover battle with Bank of Scotland. 56 Charles Allen Chairman, Granada Media (NEW). He presided over a rise in profits from pounds 480m to pounds 835m since 1996. During his reign Granada also completed pounds 730m takeover of LWT, and pounds 3.2bn hostile takeover of Forte. 57 Alan Rusbridger Editor, the Guardian (95). The Guardian won National Newspaper of the Year in 1999. The newspaper remains in Rusbridger's own words 'a radical irritant to the Government.' 58 Hans Snook Chief Executive, Orange (NEW). In May took charge of Europe's second-largest mobile-phone group with a likely market capitalisation of pounds 92bn. 59 David and Victoria Beckham Manchester United and England footballer, married to entertainer Posh Spice (69). Beckham came joint top in a Sports Council poll asking young people which sports stars they most admired. His wife is one of Britain's richest young women, and the most photographed celebrity in Britain. 60 HRH Prince Charles Windsor Prince of Wales; Heir to the throne; Duke of Cornwall (14). Prince's Trust is biggest charity of its type in Britain, and biggest single provider for the voluntary option in New Deal under which he announced pounds 50m investment scheme to create 30,000 new businesses over five years. Accused of politicising the monarchy, got Downing Street's back up with a succession of anti-GM statements. 61 Jacques Chirac President, France (18). Key European figure, though last year his presidency was jeopardised by allegations of corruption during his time as mayor of Paris. 62 Sir Brian Pitman Chairman, Lloyds TSB Group; Chairman, Next (166). Pitman engineered Lloyds' take-over of Cheltenham and Gloucester Building Society in 1995. The following year he moved up to become chairman. Lloyds TSB is the second largest internet banking operator in the UK with 250,000 customers. Next Directory is 2 per cent ahead in profits from last year. 63 Lord Norman Foster of Thames Bank Architect (132) . Designed Stansted airport, Millennium Bridge, Cambridge Law Library, Sainsbury Centre, UEA, and is designing pedestrianisation of Trafalgar Square. 64 Sir Nicholas Serota Director, Tate Gallery; Chair, Turner Prize (99). It is his vision that made Tate Britain and Tate Modern - the biggest modern art gallery in the world - the hottest tickets in town. 65 Zhu Rong-ji Chinese Premier (82). Chinese state newspapers compared Nato to Nazi Germany over attacks on Yugoslavia and the Chinese embassy. Zhu is an economic reformer renowned for his plain speaking and short temper. 66 David Trimble First Minister, Northern Ireland Assembly; Leader, Ulster Unionist Party (21). Under severe pressure within his party from those who feel that the republicans have failed to honour decommissioning targets.If his position is undermined by his own party, the peace process might be fatally wounded. 67 Chris Woodhead HM Chief Inspector of Schools (64). Has become a controversial focus of anti-liberal reaction to the 'child-centred' teaching methods of the postwar period. His influence on education policy is great. 68 Larry Ellison Chairman and CEO, Oracle (NEW). As the Information Age gives way to the Internet Age, Silicon Valley's bad boy gets revenge: database software is now the rage. Oracle's database sales surged 32%after previous sluggish growth. 69 Mario Monti Competition Commissioner, European Commission (NEW). Under the authority of Monti, the mission of Competition Directorate General is to establish and implement a coherent policy for the EU. 70 Sir Richard Wilson Cabinet Secretary and Head of the Civil Service (30). Wilson reports directly to Blair and runs the Home Civil Service. 71 Rebekah Wade Editor, News of the World (NEW) Last May Wade replaced Phil Hall and became Britain's youngest national newspaper editor. Uneasy start with 'name and shame' paedophile campaign. 72 Dr Andy Grove Chairman, Intel Corporation (41). The world's biggest computer-chip maker. In May Intel became the world's biggest company by stock-market value, skipping ahead of Microsoft and Cisco Systems. 73 Steven Spielberg Film Director and Producer; Founder, DreamWorks SKG (49). Spielberg is the most successful popular film-maker of all time, saving Hollywood with new standards for innovative direction and special effects. 74 HM Queen Elizabeth Windsor Monarch (51). Meets the PM every week. Met Camilla Parker Bowles at a Highgrove party, causing media flurry. 75 Tim Berners-Lee Director, World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) (81). Conceived the WWW in 1989 as a model of simple access and sharing information via his invention of HTML. Now director of the W3 Consortium, devoting its energies to the privacy problem. 76 Anji Hunter Special Assistant to the Prime Minister (58). Protector and friend of Blair since schooldays. Guards access to his office. 77 Gerry Adams MP President, Sinn Fein (20). Key player in Northern Ireland peace process. Announced Sinn Fein was committed to peaceful and democratic means to make progress. 78 Kofi Annan Secretary General, United Nations (16). A formidable diplomat, Annan reinvigorated the UN after his appointment in 1996. 79 Stelios Haji-Ioannou Chairman, easyGroup (185). Son of a Greek shipping magnate, founded the Luton-based no-frills airline in 1995. Now worth £187m. Moving into the world of cybercafes with the launch of easyEverything. 80 Jean-Marie Messier Chief Executive, Vivendi (NEW). VivendiNet (a joint venture between Vivendi and Canal+) and Vodafone joined forces to create Vizzavi, a multi-access internet portal that will allow customers to access personalised services such as email, address book and calendar - all via their mobile phone. 81 Professor Sir John Krebs Director, Food Standards Agency (NEW). Launched in April to provide the public with independent information and advice about food safety and standards, the agency's remit is to take an overall view across the industry from farm to fork. 82 Niall FitzGerald Chairman, Unilever (100). The newest thing the detergent industry has to a visionary has been reiterating his company's commitment to emerging markets and berating the industry for treating water and chemicals as inexhaustible resources. Sponsored the Louise Bourgeois sculptures in Tate Modern. 83 John Vickers Director General, Office of Fair Trading (NEW). The new consumers' champion, the 42-year-old former Bank of England Chief Economist will be expected to bring an end to 'Rip-off Britain'. 84 Ken Livingstone Mayor of London (NEW). The first democratically elected mayor. Quiet start, though recent appointment of Robert Kiley as 'Tube czar' may signal the start of his tenure proper. 85 Rt Hon Michael Portillo MP Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer (195). The 'Look, I have no lectern' speech at the Tory conference was praised and critiqued in equal measure. Likely challenger to Hague as future Tory leader. 86 Baroness Helena Kennedy of The Shaws QC Chairman, British Council; Chancellor, Oxford Brookes University (165). First woman to be appointed chair of the British Council. Close friend of the Blairs, produced the Kennedy Report on Education. 87 Don Cruickshank Chairman, London Stock Exchange (285). Former Oftel regulator and Chairman of Action 2000 . The tormentor of the UK banks replaces Sir John Kemp-Welch as new chairman of London Stock Exchange. 88 Professor Mike Richards National Cancer Director (cancer czar) (NEW). Former head of breast cancer research at Guy's Hospital. Will be implementing a two-week waiting time standard for all cancers. 89 Dr Thomas Michael (Mike) Dexter Director, Wellcome Trust (116). Commands a research budget of pounds 250m. Cancer biologist and not afraid to criticise the system. He was the first to discover, among other things how to grow stem cells in vitro. 90 Ian Davies Managing Director, McKinsey & Co Inc UK (227). Heads London office of international management consultancy.  Click here to read numbers 91-138

Shocked the retail world by buying Asda for £6.72bn.

Prominent europhile and business networker with unrivalled influence in oil and investment banking.

Prince William Windsor, Third in line to throne (213).

Turned 18 in June and requires PR aide to deal with media attention.

Launched Dixon's Freeserve and is due to create 2,000 jobs this year.

Raised partners and funds to save thousands of jobs at Rover.

Ace pension fund manager.

Key figure in representing consumers on issues such as GM and mobile phones.

A great populariser of science.

Stephen Lander post Director General, MI5 (NEW).

His powers should rise under Jack Straw's RIP Bill.

Long-time corporate Labour supporter.

Max Hastings Editor, the Evening Standard (133).

His paper's influence extends beyond sales.

Activist and author with the ear of Prince Charles.

Took charge of the merger between EMI and Warner Music.

Jeremy Paxman Journalist, Author and Broadcaster (103).

Still the king of the confrontational style.

Sir Geoffrey Mulcahy Chief Executive, Kingfisher (141).

Kingfisher owns of Woolworths, Comet, Superdrug and B&Q.

Lady Justice Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss Lord Justice of Appeal; President of the High Court, Family Division (202).

First woman to reach top four most senior judicial posts in England and Wales.

181
Millard (Mickey) Drexler CEO, Gap Inc (NEW).

Even label-obsessive Posh Spice shops at Gap.

182
JÙrgen Schrempp Chairman, DaimlerChrysler (NEW).

Visionary strategist masterminded world's biggest auto merger.

183
Jeff Hawkins Founder, Palm; Co-founder, Handspring (NEW).

Has overseen launch of palmtop contender, the Visor.

184
Sir Terence Conran Chairman, The Conran Shop; Conran Holdings; Conran Restaurants (168).

Sits on the business policy taskforce and is worth £100m.

185
Tony Ball Chief executive, BSkyB (NEW).

BSkyB installs more than 40,000 new digital dishes a week in the UK.

186
Professor. Richard Dawkins Professor of Public Understanding of Science, University of Oxford (92).

Called Prince Charles's comments on scientific progress 'mumbo-jumbo'.

187
Sir Martin Sorrell Group Chief Executive, WPP Group (184).

Chairs the UK's second largest advertising agency.

188
Richard Scudamore Chief executive, Premier League (NEW).

Devised bidding process for TV rights to football.

189
Shawn Fanning Founder, Napster Inc (NEW).

19-year-old whose software has huge implications for music industry.

190
Lord Charlie Falconer of Thoroton QC Minister of State, Cabinet Office; Minister responsible for the Dome (40).

Sits on 16 government committees (more than any member of the Government).

191
Paul Conroy President, Virgin Records UK; Chairman,Brit Awards (172).

From the Stones to the Spice Girls, he oversees one of the most eclectic rosters in the UK.

192
Philip Graf Chief Executive, Trinity Mirror (NEW).

Presides over the largest newspaper publisher in Europe.

Professor Stephen Young Professor of Information Engineering, Cambridge University. Chief Scientist, Entropic (118).

Spearheading new computers that can understand the human voice without error.

194
Shigeru Miyamoto General Manager, Entertainment Analysis and Development, Nintendo (NEW).

One of the most influential players in the games business.

195
Nelson Mandela Former President, South Africa (251).

Still wields a powerful influence as the 'father of South Africa'.

196
Robert-Louis Dreyfus Chairman and CEO, Adidas;Chairman at the Velodrome (206).

Also a former Saatchi & Saatchi CEO.

197
Richard Burge Chief Executive, Countryside Alliance (NEW).

Has raised profile of pro-hunting lobby group.

198
Professor Germaine Greer Writer and lecturer (NEW).

Leads the feminist voice in Britain in the absence of any clear successors.

199
Charles Saatchi Art buyer; Co-founder, M&C Saatchi (290)

Responsible for Sensation and Ant Noises exhibitions.

200
Charles Secrett Director, Friends of the Earth (36).

Inexhaustible enthusiast for his cause.

201
Lord David Puttnam of Queensgate Chairman, British Film Institute; Chairman, Enigma Productions (125).

Heads a task force on reviving the image of teachers and is 'godparent' of two Dome zones.

202
Rt Hon Michael Meacher MP Environment Minister (NEW).

In a key position, dealing with GM organisms, biotech and waste recycling.

203
Trevor Beattie Creative Director, TBWA GGT Simons Palmer (NEW).

Responsible for fcuk campaign and is to mastermind the Labour election campaign.

204<
Dr Jane E. Henney Commissioner, FDA (159).

First woman to lead the body whose approval of medicines affects stock prices worldwide.

205
George Lucas Film director (286).

The man behind Star Wars and its massive merchandising success.

206
Sir Alex Ferguson Manager, Manchester United FC (104).

Key player in the future of football.

Rt Hon Chris Smith MP Secretary for Culture, Media and Sport (NEW).

Britain's first openly gay Cabinet Minister has been at the centre of sweeping changes in the arts.

208
John McGrath Group Chief Executive, Diageo (158).

Due to retire from the world's largest drinks company. Has been appointed Boots non-executive chair.

209
Sarah Brown Managing Director, Hobsbawm Macaulay Communications; Wife of Gordon Brown (NEW).

Influence remains to be seen.

Lord David Sainsbury of Turville Science Minister (136).

One of the wealthiest men in Britain, he is in a position to influence policy on GMOs.

The Dreem Teem Garage producers/DJs (NEW).

Out of the underground and now on Radio 1, broke Speed Garage into the charts.

Adam Singer Chief Executive, Telewest (NEW).

Flextech owns 12 subscription channels and assets are thought to be on a par with Carlton.

213
Amanda Platell Communications Chief for William Hague (NEW).

Instrumental in improving Tory leader's profile.

214
Sir Malcolm Field Chairman, Civil Aviation Authority (NEW). Key figure in the proposed public-private partnership of National Air Traffic Services.

215
Lord George Robertson of Port Ellen Secretary-General, Nato (203).

Had cental role in UK's Kosovo and Iraq strategies.

216
Baroness Margaret Thatcher of Kesteven Former Prime Minister (235).

Still capable of grabbing headlines.

217
Gail Rebuck CBE Chairman and CEO, Random House UK (91).

Awarded a CBE for services to publishing.

218
Rt Hon Alistair Darling MP Social Security Secretary (119).

Has introduced significant new measures such as the New Deal for Lone Parents.

219
Rt Hon Charles Kennedy MP Leader, Liberal Democrat Party (229).

His party stormed the 'safe' Tory seat of Romsey in its by-election.

220
Lord Clive Hollick of Notting Hill Chief Executive, United News & Media (75).

Media magnate who has created waves over proposed merger with Carlton .

221
Jack M. Greenberg Chairman and CEO, McDonald's Corporation (196).

Told suppliers to stop using Monsanto's GM potatoes.

220
David Bowie Musician; internet enthusiast (NEW).

Has added publishing and online banking and art ventures to his groundbreaking back catalogue.

223
Sam Mendes Film director (NEW).

Still works for the London stage despite success of American Beauty.

224
Tiger Woods Golfer (NEW).

Idol to youngsters, gold dust to sportswear manufacturers.

225
Victoria Barnsley CEO, HarperCollins (NEW).

Ability to exert influence through vast publishing firm.

226
Julie Meyer Co-Founder, First Tuesday (NEW).

Has raised the profile of networking young e-entrepreneurs.

227
Warren Buffett Chairman, Berkshire Hathaway (88).

Investment guru is exceeded in terms of personal fortune in the US only by Bill Gates.

228
Professor Amory Lovins Co-Founder, Rocky Mountain Institute (NEW).

Adviser to governments, Oxford don and author.

229
George Cox Director-General, Institute of Directors (NEW).

One of Britain's leading business figures.

230
John Thornton President and Co-Chief Operating Officer, Goldman Sachs (NEW).

A force in finance.

231
Lord Peter Melchett Executive Director, Greenpeace UK (17).

Brought Greenpeace into the mainstream.

232
Donatella Versace Artistic Director, Versace (NEW).

Built on her brother's legacy in the fashion label forefront.

233
Sir Cameron Mackintosh Musicals producer; Chairman, Cameron Mackintosh (NEW).

His musicals have dominated the West End and world stage for nearly two decades.

234
Sir Paul Nurse Director General, Imperial Cancer Research Fund (120).

Heads institute that undertakes over one third of all UK cancer research.

235
Ian Hislop Editor, Private Eye (190).

Established anti-establishment satirist.

236
Baroness Margaret Jay of Paddington Leader of the House of Lords; Minister for Women (244).

First woman leader of the Other Place.

237
Horst Kshler Managing Director, International Monetary Fund (NEW).

Plans a reform agenda of the fund.

238
Lord Jacob Rothschild Founder, J. Rothschild Group (NEW).

Tremendously powerful in art, finance and politics, looking to expand into e-commerce.

239
Yoshiro Mori Prime Minister of Japan (NEW).

Presiding over a challenging period in Japan's economy.

240
Lord Colin Marshall of Knightsbridge Chairman, British Airways; Deputy Chairman, BT (123).

Juggles chairmanship of the London Development Partnership and Britain in Europe.

241
Jamie Oliver (aka the Naked Chef)
Chef (clothed) (NEW).

242
Max Clifford PR Consultant, Max Clifford Associates (NEW).

At the centre of many a publicity storm.

243
Marshall Bruce Mathers III (aka Eminem) Musician (NEW).

Angry young voice.

244
Arsene Wenger Manager, Arsenal FC (NEW).

Has promised to continue his successful reign until the end of his contract in 2002.

245
Venus and Serena Williams Tennis players (NEW).

Hitting the big time at last, they are role models for a generation of youngsters of all colours.

246
Tim Haines Series Producer, Walking with Dinosaurs (NEW).

Hit show has a second series in the pipeline.
247
Sir Neville Marriner Conductor; Founder and Life President, Academy of St Martin-in-the Fields (NEW).

Influential on classical scene.

248
John Pluthero Chief Executive, Freeserve (152).

Freeserve is the UK's biggest internet service provider.

249
Sir David Davies President, Royal Academy of Engineering; Director, ERA Technology; former Chief Scientific Adviser to MoD (113).

At the centre of the storm surrounding his advice to rail industry on installation of safety systems.

fields.standfirst: In this special    report we reveal the names that count
fields.trailText: In this special report we reveal the names that count...
fields.body:
Rod Eddington
Chief Executive, British Airways (NEW).

The Australian replaced Bob Ayling in May. The City expects him to deliver a return to profit, with a strategy that includes a link to a strong North American or European airline, preferably both.

Ken Kutaragi
Head of technical development, Sony Computer Entertainment (NEW).

Inventor of the PlayStation, the single most popular consumer electronics device of the past decade.

Professor Larry Summers
US Treasury Secretary (46).

Will not be coming in to help out the failing euro. Leading policymakers of the Clinton-Gore administration are focusing on a period of financial stability as top pre-election priority.

Madonna
Musician (177).

Credited with changing attitudes towards female sexuality and towards late and single parenthood. Now rooted in London.

Dr John Taylor OBE
Director General of the Research Councils (106).

Responsible for advising the DTI on allocation of the science budget and in securing the successful operation of the Research Councils in pursuit of missions.

Jac Nasser
CEO, Ford Motor Company (176).

Has already moved European headquarters from Essex to Cologne. Nasser promised extra investment at Bridgend engine plant.

Masayoshi Son
Chairman, Softbank Corporation (NEW).

Another to challenge Bill Gates as the richest man in the world. The Japanese internet entrepreneur's 38.2 per cent stake in Softbank, a worldwide force on the internet, is now worth $70bn.

Lord Thomas Bingham of Cornhill
Senior Law Lord (Former Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales) (178).

The most senior judge for England and Wales and a liberal and reforming spokesman for the judiciary.

Romano Prodi
President, European Commission (10).

Has the difficult job of restoring the Commission's reputation. Criticised Blair for failing to take a lead on the single currency.

Howard Schultz
Founder, Starbucks (NEW).

Starbucks is the new face of globalisation and wears its commitment to social responsibility on its sleeve. Yet, on the day of the Seattle riots, all 26 outlets in the city had to be shut down.

James Dyson CBE
Founder and Chairman, Dyson Research; Dyson Appliances (183).

Took on Hoover and won, with his bagless vacuum cleaner.
Charles Dunstone
Managing Director, Carphone Warehouse (105).

The business would be worth around £1 billion if floated.

Tim Koogle
Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Yahoo! (62).

Head of the world's most-visited website.

Bernard Arnault
CEO, Louis Vuitton Mo¥t Hennessy (NEW).

The owner of brands such as Dior, Givenchy, Fendi recently bought auction house Philips.

Barclay Knapp
President and CEO, NTL (221).

Ready to challenge BskyB in the battle for pay TV.

Rt Hon Stephen Byers MP
Trade and Industry Secretary (94).

Under pressure as a result of the crisis in car manufacturing.

Lord Robert Winston of Hammersmith
Professor of Fertility Studies, University of London (97).

Key spokesman in Lords in favour of embryology, now a TV favourite.

Piers Morgan
Editor, the Mirror (78).

In place despite his share-trading activities.

Scott McNealy
Chairman and CEO, Sun Microsystems (NEW).

A founding king of the internet.

Sir Andrew Turnbull
Permanent Secretary, HM Treasury (53).

One of Gordon Brown's right-hand men.

Rt Hon Dr Marjorie (Mo) Mowlam MP
Cabinet Office Secretary (38).

Will stand down at the next election.

David Liddiment
Director of Programmes, ITV (179).

News at Ten move proved treacherous.

Kevin Hand
Group Chief Executive, Emap (NEW).

Controls 150 consumer titles.

Joanne (JK) Rowling
Author, Harry Potter stories (247).

Watch out for the Potter film.

Dr Ian Bogle
Chairman, British Medical Association (265).

Wants better pay and conditions for doctors.

Dr John Sulston
Director, Sanger Centre (67).

Led the mapping of the human genome.

Dr Craig Venter
Founder and Director, Celera Genomics (NEW).

Will make a fortune through licensing his gene patents.

Dr Chris Evans OBE
Founder, Enzymatix; Founder, Celsis International; Founder, Cerebus; Founder, Chiroscience; Founder, Toad Innovations; Founder, Enviros; Founder, Merlin Ventures; Former Director of the BioIndustry Association (NEW).

Europe's leading biotechnology entrepreneur.

David Potter
Founder and Chairman, Psion (208).

Owns 20 per cent of Psion, the palm-top minicomputer and software company.

Lord George Simpson of Dunkeld
Chief Executive, Marconi Corporation (188).

GEC is set to grow through Marconi and shipbuilding.

William C. Steere Jr
Chairman and Chief Executive, Pfizer Inc (182).

Manufacturer of Viagra.

Sir John Stevens
Metropolitan Police Commissioner (NEW).

Britain's most senior police officer.

Satoshi Tajiri
Computer games creator (Pokemon) (NEW).

More than $6bn of Pokemon products have been sold.

Robert B. Shapiro
Chairman and Chief Executive, Monsanto (57).

Has influence to keep the government open-minded on GM foods.

Rt Hon Ann Widdecombe MP
Shadow Home Secretary (NEW).

Cannabis fiasco may prove fatal to career.

David Edmonds
Director-General, Oftel; Chairman, pensions taskforce (289).

Dealing with the pensions mis-selling scandal.

Lionel Jospin
Prime Minister of France (139).

The euro*s greatest supporter.

Luc Vandevelde
Chairman and Chief Executive, Marks & Spencer (NEW).

Can he turn round the ailing giant?

Alexander McQueen
Designer, Givenchy, McQueen (NEW)

Finally deemed to be hitting his stride at Givenchy.

Carly Florina
President and CEO, Hewlett-Packard (NEW).

The first woman to head a DOW30 company.

Ben Rosen
Chairman and acting Chief Executive, Compaq (121).

AltaVista has a well-known but under-developed brand in Europe.

Professor Sir John Pattison
Director of Research and Development, Department of Health (115).

Was crucial in persuading the Government to re-examine the threat of BSE.

John Humphrys
Presenter, Today Programme, BBC Radio 4; On The Record, BBC1 (84).

Puts politicians on the spot.

Professor Mervyn King
Deputy Governor, Bank of England (200).

Key economic strategist.

Philip H. Knight
Chairman and CEO, Nike Inc (205).

Just do it ... in a pair of his trainers.

Delia Smith OBE
Cookery Writer and Broadcaster (98).

£24m recipe for success.

Digby Jones
Director-General, CBI (NEW).

Influential pro-euro campaigner.

Jeff Bezos
Founder & CEO, Amazon.com (55).

Amazon has 8.5m registered customers.

webTitle: Who holds the reins of power in Britain? The top figures

fields.headline: Who holds the reins of power in Britain? The top figures
fields.standfirst: In this special    report we reveal the names that count
fields.trailText: In this special report we reveal the names that count...
fields.body:
Rt Hon Tony Blair MP Prime Minister; Leader of the Labour Party (1).

Rt Hon Gordon Brown MP Chancellor of the Exchequer (3).

Alan Greenspan Chairman, American Federal Bank Reserve (7).

The man revered as the architect of the unprecedented economic boom in the US is facing his biggest test. His every pout, strut, and subtle change in syntax or vocabulary is analysed and counter-analysed by global markets. His greatest test may come after next month's Presidential elections. The Fed, although politically independent, has held off from changing interest rates in the run-up to the polls. Greenspan, originally appointed by Ronald Reagan, was accused of losing George Bush Sr the 1992 election after interest rate hikes just before the poll. With the US trade deficit spiralling out of control and growth still stellar, Greenspan will be responsible for 'the soft landing' of the economy. Despite all the adulation he has received in the past, it is this job which will prove the ultimate test of his mythical abilities, and may prove the difference between global boom or global slump.


Steve Case Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, AOL; chairman designate, AOL-Time Warner (59).

If, in 10 years' time, the impact of the internet amounts to a fraction of the wild claims made for it now, then much of the credit will go to Steve Case. The proposed £128 billion merger of his company, America Online with Time Warner, itself trying to merge with UK music group, EMI, represents the first conjuncture of old and new media. He barely registered on last year's list but this year he was the star of the show at the Davos World Economic Forum, eclipsing even Bill Gates, and he was proclaimed king of the new establishment by the US glossies. The creation of AOL-Time Warner is the practical manifestation of digital convergence. Television, movies, music and computer games will be available on demand in homes over high-speed data links. Case was in a position to broker the deal because AOL was among that rarest of breeds: the profit-making internet company.

Alastair Campbell Press Secretary to the Prime Minister (5).

Sir Eddie George Governor, Bank of England (8).

'Steady but ready' Eddie's influence over interest rates has strengthened over the past year. He has made the casting vote in the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee on at least two occasions, keeping mortgage costs constant since February. Sir Edward became Governor of the Bank of England in 1993. His term was renewed for a further five years in 1998, his powers then greatly enhanced by Labour's granting of operational independence to the Bank in 1997, but weakened by the removal of regulatory powers over the financial sector. Last month he helped coordinate an international effort to prop up the ailing euro. But he is a noted eurosceptic, and as the Chancellor has tempered his euro-enthusiasm, and the economy prospered, so the relationship between the two men has improved. They now get on well.

Bill Clinton President of United States of America (4).

Clinton's foreign policy often lays the foundation for the UK's. Labour modelled its election campaign on the 1992 Clinton victory; Blair used Clinton to promote peace in Northern Ireland. The United States dominated Nato policy over Kosovo, refusing to deploy US ground troops. Refused to assist Blair to forge a republican compromise on the RUC issue, which Clinton thinks should be addressed as outlined in the Patten report. Recently his influence in the Mid-East has been questioned. Such is the ephemeral nature of political power that Clinton - whose term ends in January- is unlikely to figure in this list next year.

Bill Gates Chairman, Microsoft (2).

The past 12 months have not been a great year for the world's richest man. The software guru has suffered the ignominy of having his company branded a monopoly by the US government which is now examining ways of breaking the firm up. Nevertheless Gates, 44, is still worth more than $60bn and it is far from certain that Microsoft will do the splits. Slow to realise the importance of the internet, Gates is now refocusing Microsoft into a company which aims to write the code for the next generation of internet-compatible devices. Disliked by some for the way his company has dominated the industry, Gates, married with two children, does not outwardly give the impression of being a bully. Quiet and reserved Gates has pledged to give away 95 per cent of his wealth to civic and philanthropic causes when he dies.

Rupert Murdoch Chairman and Chief Executive, News Corporation (6).

Four million daily Sun readers and the 700,000 Times readers. His Sunday Times and News of the World are formidable money-making machines. In BSkyB Murdoch has 40 per cent and effective control of Western Europe's most profitable broadcaster. Was diagnosed with low grade prostate cancer recently, so speculation mounts that he is grooming a successor. His son Lachlan was last week appointed deputy at News Corp and seems the sibling most likely. As the election nears there will again be speculation as to the influence Murdoch wields over his editors.


Sir John Browne Chief executive, BP Amoco; Trustee of the British Museum (23).

It has often been said of Sir John Browne that he wields more power and has more influence over our lives than the aver age minister. After September's fuel crisis demonstrated Government impotence in guaranteeing petrol supplies, and its inability to force oil companies to ensure them, the Prime Minister may himself ruefully reflect on the truth of this remark. Browne has built BP from an important, but second tier oil company, to a global 'supermajor' capable of competing with the likes of Exxon. Two significant deals - the purchase of US oil company Amoco for pounds 30bn in 1998 and its subsequent acquisition of Arco pounds 18bn - have propelled the company to a market value of nearly pounds 138 bn and to the second slot in the FTSE 100 index.

Highest new entry
John Chambers President and CEO, Cisco Systems Inc.

Chambers, 51, is the man who wired the world. His company, Cisco, makes the hardware and software which powers the internet. It does all the back-end, boring stuff which means that it is set to benefit massively from the demand for e-business solutions. 'Are you ready?' runs the company's ads heralding the internet revolution. Cisco certainly was and its share price soared 50,000 per cent in a decade. Chambers is the internet revolution's biggest cheerleader and is the biggest critic. Cisco became the most valuable firm in the US earlier this year when it temporarily overtook Microsoft.


Chris Gent Chief Executive, Vodafone (31).

UK's market leader in mobile phones, Vodafone's coup de grace was the takeover of German telecom company Mannesmann, valuing it at more than £82 billion. Has become the world's biggest mobile phone operator.

Rt Hon Peter Mandelson MP Northern Ireland Secretary (25).

Returned to Cabinet after only 10 months in wilderness. After initial success, the peace process now seems precariously balanced in the face of Unionist opposition and republican refusal to compromise.

Jonathan Powell Downing Street Chief of Staff (9).

Became Tony Blair's chief of staff in 1995. Acts as the PM's fixer, liaising with civil servants, and behind-the-scenes Northern Ireland envoy. Refuted allegations that he masterminded whispering campaigns against Mo Mowlam and Frank Dobson.

Nobuyuki Idei President and CEO, Sony Corporation (154).

Leader of the world's largest corporation since 1995. Sony pioneered the video recorder, Walkman and Mini-Disc. His are the slogans 'Digital Dream Kids' and 'ReGeneration'.

Greg Dyke Director General, BBC (11).

His appointment provoked William Hague to spend £100,000 on media analysts to monitor BBC output. Drastic shake-up is already under way, with rout of middle management. He has even banned croissants at morning meetings to save costs.

Marjorie Scardino CEO, Pearson (48).

First female executive of a FTSE 100 company. Former Chief Executive of the Economist, her influence as head of a company that owns the FT, Economist, Penguin Books, Baywatch and Madame Tussaud's secured her number eight slot in Fortune 's list of most powerful women. Shares have doubled in two years.

Rt Hon David Blunkett MP Education and Employment Secretary (27).

Has direct responsibility for two of the government's key policies: raising school standards and New Deal. Launched inquiry into the marking of national curriculum tests for 11 year olds, and has introduced 'citizenship' classes.

Rt Hon John Prescott MP Deputy Prime Minister; Secretary for Environment, Transport and the Regions (13).

Presides over an annual transport budget of pounds 3.7bn and housing budget of pounds 2.4bn. Joined Brown behind the 'forces of privilege' campaign. Offered somewhat too eagerly to take reins in running the country so Blair could take paternity leave.

Gerry Robinson Chairman, Granada Group; Chairman, Arts Council (39).

Granada own a third of the ITV network. At the Arts Council Robinson is in charge of pounds 384 million of government and lottery money. Sits on the Creative Industries taskforce.

Rt Hon Jack Straw MP Home Secretary (28).

Remains a figure of calm as storms rage over Labour but...criticised over watering down of Freedom of Information Bill; under pressure to introduce race reforms in the wake of the Lawrence report; criticised over Asylum Bill and voucher system for refugees.

Rt Hon Robin Cook MP Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs Secretary (44).

Has been kept busy with Zimbabwe, Sierra Leone and Chechnya, and has frozen military exports to Zimbabwe. Has been pressing Blair to enter the European single currency at an earlier date.

Paul Dacre Editor, Daily Mail (19).

The Mail outstripped the Daily Mirror's circulation for the first time in 1998, selling 2,421,319, the second highest among UK dailies. Instigated anti-GM foods campaign. Jumped on the asylum-seekers bandwagon, portraying many of them as bogus and thieves.

Sir Richard Sykes Chairman and Chief Executive, Glaxo Wellcome (22).

Appointed by Blair to the Council for Science and Technology, he opened the Edward Jenner Institute for vaccine research, to which Glaxo contributed pounds 10m. In May 1999 was named Business Leader of the Year. Paid pounds 3.63m last year.


Sir Richard Branson Founder & Chairman, Virgin (32).

Recently sold extracts of his autobiography Losing My Virginity to the Sun while a rival paper extracted Tom Bower's less flattering and unauthorised biography. Still hoping to land licence for National Lottery.

Sir Peter Bonfield Chief Executive, British Telecommunications; Non-executive director, AstraZeneca (26).

BT Cellnet will have stolen a march on competitors if its launch of the UK's first high-speed internet access succeeds.

Lord Derry Irvine of Lairg QC Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain (33).

Mark Moody-Stuart Group Chairman, Royal Dutch Shell (77).

David Yelland Editor, the Sun (54).
As editor of the best-selling daily tabloid his influence will grow as the election looms and as the debate over the Euro becomes sharper.

Louis Gerstner Chairman and CEO, IBM (93).

Heading the US computer giant since 1993, he has taken its total assets to $86bn.


Michael Eisner Chairman, Walt Disney Corporation (47).

In his 14-year tenure Disney's market value has risen from $2bn to $75bn. But he lost in legal battle against former deputy Jeffrey Katzenberg over loss of earnings.


Steve Jobs Interim CEO, Co-founder Apple Computer Inc (68).

Back in the limelight, turning the fortunes of Apple around with the new iMac. Results show increased demand for PowerMac G4 and new PowerBooks.


Linus Torvalds Programmer; originated Linux operating system (153).

Bill Gates's nemesis: a Finnish student who wrote an operating system to run his own computer seven years ago and then publicised its code on the internet so other programmers could copy, refine and develop it. System took pounds 1.25bn worth of business from Microsoft's Windows last year.
fields.bodyText: Rt Hon Tony Blair MP Prime Minister; Leader of the Labour Party (1). Rt Hon Gordon Brown MP Chancellor of the Exchequer (3). Alan Greenspan Chairman, American Federal Bank Reserve (7). The man revered as the architect of the unprecedented economic boom in the US is facing his biggest test. His every pout, strut, and subtle change in syntax or vocabulary is analysed and counter-analysed by global markets. His greatest test may come after next month's Presidential elections. The Fed, although politically independent, has held off from changing interest rates in the run-up to the polls. Greenspan, originally appointed by Ronald Reagan, was accused of losing George Bush Sr the 1992 election after interest rate hikes just before the poll. With the US trade deficit spiralling out of control and growth still stellar, Greenspan will be responsible for 'the soft landing' of the economy. Despite all the adulation he has received in the past, it is this job which will prove the ultimate test of his mythical abilities, and may prove the difference between global boom or global slump. Steve Case Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, AOL; chairman designate, AOL-Time Warner (59). If, in 10 years' time, the impact of the internet amounts to a fraction of the wild claims made for it now, then much of the credit will go to Steve Case. The proposed £128 billion merger of his company, America Online with Time Warner, itself trying to merge with UK music group, EMI, represents the first conjuncture of old and new media. He barely registered on last year's list but this year he was the star of the show at the Davos World Economic Forum, eclipsing even Bill Gates, and he was proclaimed king of the new establishment by the US glossies. The creation of AOL-Time Warner is the practical manifestation of digital convergence. Television, movies, music and computer games will be available on demand in homes over high-speed data links. He has made the casting vote in the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee on at least two occasions, keeping mortgage costs constant since February. Sir Edward became Governor of the Bank of England in 1993. His term was renewed for a further five years in 1998, his powers then greatly enhanced by Labour's granting of operational independence to the Bank in 1997, but weakened by the removal of regulatory powers over the financial sector. Last month he helped coordinate an international effort to prop up the ailing euro. Bill Clinton President of United States of America (4). Clinton's foreign policy often lays the foundation for the UK's. Labour modelled its election campaign on the 1992 Clinton victory; Blair used Clinton to promote peace in Northern Ireland. The United States dominated Nato policy over Kosovo, refusing to deploy US ground troops. Refused to assist Blair to forge a republican compromise on the RUC issue, which Clinton thinks should be addressed as outlined in the Patten report. Recently his influence in the Mid-East has been questioned. Such is the ephemeral nature of political power that Clinton - whose term ends in January- is unlikely to figure in this list next year. Bill Gates Chairman, Microsoft (2). The past 12 months have not been a great year for the world's richest man. The software guru has suffered the ignominy of having his company branded a monopoly by the US government which is now examining ways of breaking the firm up. Nevertheless Gates, 44, is still worth more than $60bn and it is far from certain that Microsoft will do the splits. Slow to realise the importance of the internet, Gates is now refocusing Microsoft into a company which aims to write the code for the next generation of internet-compatible devices. Disliked by some for the way his company has dominated the industry, Gates, married with two children, does not outwardly give the impression of being a bully. Quiet and reserved Gates has pledged to give away 95 per cent of his wealth to civic and philanthropic causes when he dies. Rupert Murdoch Chairman and Chief Executive, News Corporation (6). Four million daily Sun readers and the 700,000 Times readers. His Sunday Times and News of the World are formidable money-making machines. In BSkyB Murdoch has 40 per cent and effective control of Western Europe's most profitable broadcaster. Was diagnosed with low grade prostate cancer recently, so speculation mounts that he is grooming a successor. His son Lachlan was last week appointed deputy at News Corp and seems the sibling most likely. As the election nears there will again be speculation as to the influence Murdoch wields over his editors. Sir John Browne Chief executive, BP Amoco; Trustee of the British Museum (23). It has often been said of Sir John Browne that he wields more power and has more influence over our lives than the aver age minister. After September's fuel crisis demonstrated Government impotence in guaranteeing petrol supplies, and its inability to force oil companies to ensure them, the Prime Minister may himself ruefully reflect on the truth of this remark. Browne has built BP from an important, but second tier oil company, to a global 'supermajor' capable of competing with the likes of Exxon. Two significant deals - the purchase of US oil company Amoco for pounds 30bn in 1998 and its subsequent acquisition of Arco pounds 18bn - have propelled the company to a market value of nearly pounds 138 bn and to the second slot in the FTSE 100 index. Highest new entry John Chambers President and CEO, Cisco Systems Inc. Chambers, 51, is the man who wired the world. His company, Cisco, makes the hardware and software which powers the internet. It does all the back-end, boring stuff which means that it is set to benefit massively from the demand for e-business solutions. 'Are you ready?' runs the company's ads heralding the internet revolution. Cisco certainly was and its share price soared 50,000 per cent in a decade. Chambers is the internet revolution's biggest cheerleader and is the biggest critic. Cisco became the most valuable firm in the US earlier this year when it temporarily overtook Microsoft. Chris Gent Chief Executive, Vodafone (31). UK's market leader in mobile phones, Vodafone's coup de grace was the takeover of German telecom company Mannesmann, valuing it at more than £82 billion. webTitle: The power 300 panel

fields.headline: The power 300 panel
fields.standfirst: The panel of judges deciding who should or should not make the Power 300 list have each themselves made  impressive contributions to British life
fields.trailText: The panel of judges deciding who should or should not make the Power 300 list have each themselves made impressive contributions to British life.
fields.body:
Will Hutton

Chief executive, the Industrial Society Hutton's career in journalism started in 1978. He joined the Guardian in 1990, and became editor in chief of The Observer in 1998, before taking up his job with the Industrial Society this year. His books include The State We're In (1994).

Tamara Ingram

Chief executive officer, Saatchi & Saatchi Ingram joined Saatchi in 1985 and worked across a variety of brands from NSPCC to Visa International, becoming chief executive in 1995. She sits on the Board of the London Development Agency.

Rachel Newsome

Deputy editor of style and culture magazine Dazed and Confused. Newsome has written in music magazines and national newspapers, and appeared on TV and radio speaking about youth culture and brands. She was NUS/Guardian Student Journalist of the Year in 1994.

Lord Powell

Charles Powell has been a director of Jardine Matheson Holdings since 1991, of National Westminster Bank (1991-2000) and LVMH since 1995. This year he became chairman of Phillips Auctioneers. From 1983-1991 he was Private Secretary to the Prime Minister.

Heather Rabbatts

Began her career as a barrister, representing among others the Greenham Common women. In 1987, she joined Hammersmith and Fulham Council and later became chief executive of the London Borough of Lambeth. She is a governor of the LSE and BBC.

Lewis Wolpert

Author of Malignant Sadness: The Anatomy of Depression (1999), which looks at what science, psychiatry and his experience could reveal about depression. He is a professor at the Royal Free and University College Medical School London and Fellow of the Royal Society.

Peter York

In 1975 he co-founded the strategic consultancy company SRU Ltd. His specialism is the redevelopment of brands that have lost focus.notHe is a commentator on lifestyle and social change and sits on the Government task forces on teaching and on rebranding Britain.
