webTitle: The net won't kill the office

fields.headline: The net won't kill the office
fields.standfirst: The virtual world has a role, but the workplace will remain as a hub of innovation, writes  Richard Scase
fields.trailText: The virtual world has a role, but the workplace will remain as a hub of innovation, writes Richard Scase
fields.body:
The internet revolution, say the pundits, raises the possibility of the virtual organisation, allowing people to work from home, their back gardens or even their favourite holiday destinations. The era of the interconnected, wired corporation will see the end of the traditional boundaries between home, the workplace and leisure.

If this were true, it would dramatically affect all our institutions. It could be truly stated that the information age is structured on quite different principles from those of the industrial economy. Commuting, like the office block and the central business district, would be a thing of the past. Congestion and traffic pollution would disappear. The very basis of urbanism as a way of life would be redundant.

How realistic is this scenario? For a start, it is questionable whether knowledge-based jobs will be in a majority. Other workers - check-out staff, healthcare workers, teachers and those delivering personal services - will always need to travel to work to earn a living. But even for knowledge workers, it is unlikely to be the end of commuting to work.

This is because the modern corporation can only be competitive through continuous innovation.

Innovation depends on creativity. And a key factor in creativity is sociability. So although knowledge employees may technically be able to work from home, it will re-main necessary for them to meet each other, to interact and to brainstorm. It is through face-to-face contact between colleagues that ideas for new products, business leads and problem-solving emerge. This makes the physical workplace just as important in the future organisation as now. How do companies encourage sociability?

The first step is to create effective team dynamics in which personal compatibilities are as important as technical skills. Witness how this is given priority by advertising agencies, publishing houses, R&D departments and sales teams. Colleagues need to get on with each other and have fun together.

Consider also workplace architecture. Many companies are redesigning their workplaces around centrally located cafes to encourage socialisation between colleagues who would otherwise rarely meet. In their physical layout, management consultancies and software design firms often resemble airport lounges with their sofas or-ganised around vending machines.

For many companies, geographical location is regarded as of utmost importance, even in this age of the much-heralded death of distance. Again, this is to encourage sociability. The reason so many knowledge-based businesses remain in London, despite its congestion and high rental costs, is the cluster factor. The proximity of pubs, restaurants and wine bars enables colleagues to stay in contact out of work. From this, many new business ideas develop.

Move to an out-of-town site with excellent facilities and lower costs and the business can die because of the lack of after-hours informal socialisation. For this reason Philips moved some of its design functions from Eindhoven to Amsterdam. It offers a buzz that attracts young creative staff as well as an infrastructure that allows it to flourish.

For many companies, corporate events are organised to foster employee sociability. Although the formal agenda may be to approve strategic plans, their real contribution is to bring together colleagues who would otherwise never see each other. This is particularly important for global corporations. Their project teams may be organised to interact through internet technologies but for trust and the exchange of ideas to develop, periodic face-to-face sociability is vital.

All such approaches to encouraging sociability at-tempt to nurture tacit knowledge - to encourage colleagues to understand how others work. This strengthens our own personal competencies but at the same time makes us inter-dependent. Because we work well together, we become good at this because others are good at that. I can concentrate on developing my strengths and so can you. We understand how each other thinks and how we each prefer to do different things in an informal but clearly understood division of labour. Only face-to-face sociability allows this to happen.

This is why some high-spending football clubs fail to realise their true potential. Buying star players is not enough. Look at Chelsea. To be successful, each player needs to understand how his teammates think. On-the-pitch training is not a substitute for socialisation - which is why many managers turn a blind eye to some of their players' extramural antics.

Equally, corporate success is not achieved by hiring superstars. The real key to high performance is combining in-dividual talents through shared understanding and 'hidden' tacit knowledge gained through intense or-ganisational sociability. Many small firms are good at this, particularly if they are located in geographical clusters that facilitate after-hours contacts.

Internet technologies will change the ways we work. We will work more from home and communicate with colleagues across greater distances. But this will not make the workplace redundant. Rather, workplaces will be-come think-tanks to stimulate corporate creativity and innovation. Generating and managing tacit knowledge through colleague sociability will be a major challenge. A revolution in management practices will be required if sociability is to be combined with the internet to achieve competitive success.

It's a dating agency, a social circle... and a job

As old forms of community break down, people are increasingly reliant on the workplace for sociability and a sense of belonging, according to a report by careers consultancy Sanders & Sidney.

The report, Friendship Works, shows that sociability is an important element in people's decision to join - and stay with - a company and commit themselves more to work. Two-thirds of respondents said that a sense of community compensated for discontents such as pay.

The office has also become much more than a place to work; 80 per cent of employees make friendships that extend beyond the office, and a quarter meet their partner there. Although the report finds that friendship and community have strong business benefits in staff retention and motivation, only 8 per cent of organisations have formal policies for fostering them. A resounding 94 per cent of employees think their employers are missing a trick.

Richard Scase is author of Britain in 2010 (Capstone Publishing, 2000) and a professor at the University of Kent

webTitle: Confer and conquer...

fields.headline: Confer and conquer...
fields.standfirst: The days when a conference was regarded as a jolly are over. Now delegates are even given homework, reports  Alexander Garrett
fields.trailText: The days when a conference was regarded as a jolly are over. Now delegates are even given homework, reports Alexander Garrett
fields.body:
So the political conference season is over, and the rallying calls and hectoring cries are left to echo in the rafters of seaside halls from Brighton to Bournemouth. For thousands of others from all walks of life, however, the glad-handing, the fiddling with registration badges and resisting the allure of yet another chicken drumstick is just about to begin.

Conferences have become a recurring event in many people's working lives. Last year, some 656,100 were held in the UK, according to the British Conference Market Trends Survey - although half of those involved fewer than 20 people. They range from a group of colleagues meeting in a small hotel room somewhere off the A1 to full-blown international conventions with thousands of delegates flying in from around the world. The cost of all this meeting was somewhere in the very wide range of £1.8 billion to £5bn, depending on whose estimate you believe.

But are conferences worthwhile, and what should you really expect to get out of them?

The very term conference covers a multitude of sins. There are corporate conferences to launch a product, to rally the sales force, or to keep your customers informed of developments; then there are 'association' conferences in which members of a profession or a trade come together to discuss the latest trends and knowledge in their sphere.

David Campbell, managing director of conference organiser Banks Sadler, prefers another distinction, though. 'There are two kinds of conferences,' he says, 'the one I am told to go to; and the one I elect or even pay to go to.' The difference, he says, is that in the latter case, somebody is likely to have a much clearer idea of what they want to get out of the conference at the outset.

Tony Rogers, executive director of the British Association of Conference Destinations, as well as the Association of British Professional Conference Organisers, says that people don't just go to conferences to hear what the speakers have to say. He says networking and interacting with colleagues - both in working sessions and meal breaks - are at the top of the list of reasons given. 'There is also motivation, taking stock, recharging batteries and receiving encouragement from peers. Many people nowadays are working on their own or in small teams.'

The nature of conferences is also changing. Although there are more taking place, they tend to be shorter, due to pressure on people's time, and increasingly interactive. Once it was enough to simply attend and listen, perhaps sinking into your seat to enjoy a nap during the less riveting presentations. Nowadays, though, you are expected to identify the 'break-out' sessions that meet your special interests, and to fully participate in working on problems or debating with the chairperson. If you're really unlucky, your contribution (or lack of it) may be recorded in the conference notes that are available to your bosses and colleagues.

If you really want to get the most out of a conference, you should prepare beforehand: studying the programme notes, finding out more about the sessions that interest you, and scouring the delegates' list for people you can arrange to meet. Once there, you should get yourself noticed by announcing your name and position every time you ask a question, introduce yourself to key speakers and ensure your wallet is brimming with business cards to distribute at the inevitable cocktail party.

Rogers says that while it was common in the 1980s for conferences to be regarded as something of a jolly, such frivolity is more likely to be frowned upon today. 'There is generally a much stronger business focus, and the emphasis is on obtaining the skills and ideas that you are going to need at work. People now work much longer hours at conference,' he adds. 'Sometimes they are even given homework in the evening.'

However, while cities like Birmingham and Manchester continue to provide important venues, it is no coincidence that some of the most prestigious conferences take place at locations such as Cannes, Paris, Disneyworld in Florida or San Diego. And while no political party has yet dared to hold its annual conference aboard an ocean-going liner, it is a tactic increasingly being relied upon in the commercial world. Not only is there the whiff of exclusivity that comes with such a venue, but you are ensured of a captive audience.

And for some people, high jinks will always be part of the conference experience. Maybe it is the escape from office supervision, or just finding yourself in a strange city, but there will always be a handful of normally sober delegates in a nightclub dancing the conga at 3am.

Considering the scale of the conference industry, it is curious that research on their cost or whether they are worth the time seems so elusive. Sally Greenhill, of consultants The Right Solution, says: 'Companies are increasingly evaluating their conferences after the event, but the missing element is whether they get a return on their investment. For example, if an event is held to launch a new product, there seems to be little attempt to link the event to sales of the product, and most of the evidence is anecdotal.'

Just accommodation costs, including meals, will eat up £125 to £300 per person every 24 hours for a conference in the UK, and that doesn't take account of travel, registration fees, or the cost of your not being at work.

If your employer decides to send you, they must think you're worth it. There are inevitable hazards: grotty food, uncomfortable beds and even dodgy air conditioning. (Legionnaire's disease is named after a group of US army veterans who went down with the bug while attending a conference.)

But conferences are a good way to participate in your industry, says Campbell, and as such they can only be helpful to your career. So perhaps there's only one thing worse than being asked to attend a three-day meeting of loss assessors in Loughborough, and that's not being asked at all.

Spotting a successful conference

 Are delegates asked about special needs?
Some 20 per cent of delegates now register as vegetarian. If non-smoking accommodation and wheelchair access are provided, these are signs that the organisers have delegates' comfort at heart.

 Is it somewhere interesting but accessible?
More people will be drawn to an exotic location but they've still got to get there. Trip to Nice? Definitely. To Nepal? Maybe next time.

 Is it longer than three days?
If it is, it's unlikely to attract 'key decision makers' - they'll be back in the office, making key decisions.

webTitle: Union is harming my fight for job

fields.headline: Union is harming my fight for job
fields.trailText: I have been involved in very difficult discussions with my employers which could result in my dismissal. Inefficient union officials have added to the problem. When I was involved in a grievance procedure, they failed to produce pages of minutes that would have proved my case. Now they seem reluctant to tell me how my dismissal negotiations are going.
fields.body:
I have been involved in very difficult discussions with my employers which could result in my dismissal. Inefficient union officials have added to the problem. When I was involved in a grievance procedure, they failed to produce pages of minutes that would have proved my case. Now they seem reluctant to tell me how my dismissal negotiations are going.

You could take your union to court and perhaps win compensation if it breached its duties to represent you effectively. This, however, is a very difficult procedure. If you wanted to try it, you might get free advice from a law centre. You might also think seriously about trying to achieve a settlement with them rather than ending up in court. If poor representation did lead to your dismissal, your case against the union would be easier.

You have the right to withdraw your authority for the union to represent you. Your employer would then have to negotiate with you, or with someone else you nominated. But it might be better to ask the union's head office to supply another representative. Some union officials do let clients down. Others dawdle on cases they think are weak. If that were so, they should be frank rather than let you down painfully and slowly.

Legal advice from Lewis Silkin.

webTitle: Ganguly sets up final showdown

fields.headline: Ganguly sets up final showdown
fields.trailText: Sourav Ganguly's unbeaten innings of 141 ensured India's impressive passage to tomorrow's final of the International Cricket Council's Knockout 2000 trophy.
fields.body:
Sourav Ganguly's unbeaten innings of 141 ensured India's impressive passage to tomorrow's final of the International Cricket Council's Knockout 2000 trophy.

A showdown here between New Zealand and India may not have been predicted but, having beaten Australia and now South Africa in their past two matches, India deserve their place.

Ganguly did not make many friends at Lancashire during the summer - he was regarded as a solitary figure - but he remains one of the world's leading batsmen, especially in one-day cricket.

His innings came from only 142 balls and, with Sachin Tendulkar, Rahul Dravid and the new sensation Yuvraj Singh also batting punishingly, India swept to 295 for six from their 50 overs.

After losing four wickets in the opening eight overs, South Africa never looked like threatening India's score. Even with Mark Boucher making 60, their losing margin was still 95 runs.

South Africa were a shadow of the team that crushed England by eight wickets in the quarter-final on Tuesday.

Once Tendulkar had made his usual early charge - Roger Telemachus was the principal sufferer this time - Ganguly dominated India's innings. With exquisite timing, the left-hander struck Nicky Boje for three sixes in two overs and Jacques Kallis was subjected to a ferocious assault in the closing overs.

Dravid was as polished as ever during his partnership of 145 from 25 overs with Ganguly. Then Yuvraj, who made 84 from 80 balls against Australia last Saturday in his first one-day international innings, scored 41 from 35 deliveries before being brilliantly held by Jonty Rhodes, diving forward at long-on.

Yuvraj's age has been declared as anything between 18 and 21 - most people are settling for 19 - and he is clearly a precocious talent. He produced a dazzling array of sweetly timed shots against Australia, but yesterday he relied more on brute force.

India would have topped 300 but for losing four wickets in their final seven balls. Allan Donald's figures of two for 34 from 10 overs were outstanding in the midst of such carnage.

Gary Kirsten, run out going for a third, and Kallis, who skied to mid-on, self-destructed as South Africa quickly lost two men who could anchor a decent run chase. Rhodes and Boucher rattled along at more than five an over, but those early wickets meant there was no room for error.

When Rhodes was wonderfully caught on the midwicket boundary by Venkatesh Prasad, who held the ball high above his head and then managed to remain inside the rope as he fell, South Africa's chances effectively ended.

Sir Paul Condon, the head of the ICC's anti-corruption unit, will make a special presentation to the ICC's executive board here next week to explain the structure and remit of his work.

The council is investing £2.7m in its campaign, which was launched after match-rigging scandals enveloped the game this year.

The disgraced former South African captain Hansie Cronje was banned for life on Wednesday after he admitted receiving money from bookmakers, and the former Pakistan captain Salim Malik and his Indian counterpart Kapil Dev have also been at the centre of various corruption charges in recent months.

The meeting is also expected to ratify the issuing of declaration forms to all international players, umpires, ref- erees, officials, administrators, employees and groundsmen.

webTitle: Counties hit out over £3m shortfall

fields.headline: Counties hit out over £3m shortfall
fields.standfirst: Lamb under threat as players attack ECB over pay cuts and job losses
fields.trailText: The future of Tim Lamb as chief executive of the England and Wales Cricket Board has been placed under threat following an acrimonious meeting of the First Class Forum.
fields.body:
The future of Tim Lamb as chief executive of the England and Wales Cricket Board has been placed under threat following an acrimonious meeting of the First Class Forum.

Lamb is believed to have come under pressure from those counties dissatisfied with the level of expenditure at the ECB when they themselves are anticipating a cut in revenue from the board following a £3m shortfall in income this summer.

The ECB chairman Lord MacLaurin, who has just been re-elected for a further two years, said yesterday that Lamb had the board's "full and unequivocal support" but that carries with it the same overtones as those of football chairmen shortly before the axe falls.

MacLaurin usually attends meetings of the forum as an observer although he is not required to do so, but this time he chose not to appear. This has been interpreted as the chairman distancing himself from his chief executive.

Lamb has come under further pressure this week from the county players. Following last week's annual meeting of the Professional Cricketers' Association, a strongly worded letter, signed by the PCA chief executive David Graveney, its chairman Matthew Fleming and president Mike Gatting, was sent to Lord MacLaurin and other board members, outlining their fears and complaints about the way the game is being administered. It is believed to have stopped short of actually demanding Lamb's resignation but it came close.

Specifically, the 400 professional cricketers who belong to the union are concerned that the shortfall in central income, which almost certainly will mean a drop in income to each county of around £50,000, is already having an effect with promised pay increases not materialising, some players being asked to take a cut and contracts not being renewed.

A paring of county staff has always been on the agenda and it has long been felt that there are too many players of modest standard with no future in the game being subsidised when the money could be more gainfully spent.

But there is genuine concern from players and their employers that the cutbacks are being made because the central administration, while speaking positively, is paying little more than lip service to the county game.

Administrators will say that the shortfall has been caused by what was always perceived as a lacklustre series against Zimbabwe coming in under budget and that income from the much higher-profile series against West Indies was damaged by the games at Edgbaston and Headingley that lasted three and two days respectively and so deprived them of profits from a potential three full houses over those weekends.

But the 18 first-class counties have backed the ECB and are confident their financial difficulties will be overcome. David Morgan, who is chairman of the forum, said: "Nobody could have foreseen that so many Test matches would end so prematurely this summer and this is the root cause of cricket's financial difficulties at the moment.

"The First Class Forum understands this and has every faith in the ECB management to resolve matters. The successful summer that England enjoyed has given cricket a far better operating climate in which to develop our commercial activities, and that can only be good."

However, MacLaurin is believed to be angered by the inability to find a successor to Cornhill as sponsor of home Test matches.

 Duncan Fletcher has been rewarded for his promising first year as England coach by being given the chance to guide them beyond the next World Cup in South Africa in three years' time. Fletcher yesterday accepted a two-year extension to his contract.

webTitle: Crozier faces up to a crazy new world

fields.headline: Crozier faces up to a crazy new world
fields.trailText: Adam Crozier's masterplan for an England revival did not bank on the sort of week we've just been through.
fields.body:
What a difference a week makes. Just before England's game with Germany I spoke to Adam Crozier who was full of optimism about the way his new, spangly Football Association was going to meet the challenges of the 21st century. Flip charts, flow charts, three-year audits, 10-year plans: he had the lot. Then, bang.

It is difficult to know what has been the worst aspect of the FA chief executive's week, England at the bottom of their World Cup group, the resignation of the coach on whom he pinned such faith or the fact that his caretaker manager appears not to understand the point of substitutions ("I couldn't bring on Michael Owen because I knew Emile Heskey was suffering from a bad back": thanks for that, Howard).

To cap it all Crozier was symbolically photographed by the tabloids while playing for the media team in Finland with his feet apparently moving in several different directions at once.

Now Crozier knows he faces the real test of his mettle. When making his choice for the future coach of the national side he has to balance two conflicting forces: on the one hand, the French experience suggests success comes only from the long term, from planning and co-ordination; on the other, he needs someone pronto to paper over the deepening fissures in the national team. To paraphrase the old gag about the yokel giving directions to a lost motorist, if Crozier wants to get to his destination, it would be a lot better if he did not start from here.

Begin, perhaps, from the positions of strength that were in evidence in the autumns of 1990 and 1996, when a winning coach could have brought in a young assistant to learn the ropes at his side in an atmosphere of achievement. Not once but twice, however, the bloated egos bursting out of FA blazers scuppered any hope of con solidation by removing successful coaches at the very peak of their powers.

What Crozier seems to understand is that he needs to construct a collegiate system of the best minds in English football working together for the common good, an Anfield boot room for the larger stage. Unfortunately he has somewhat undermined that concept already by suggesting that the top man in this structure need not hold coaching qualifications.

This is odd, since one of his proudest achievements in his short tenure is that the FA has recently persuaded all clubs to insist on such requirements in their choice of future managers.

Besides, surely we now appreciate that coaching is everything. Craig Brown's consistent over-achievement with mediocre resources has shown that a bit of tactical nous goes considerably further in the international game than an ability to quote passages from Henry V in the dressing room. Brown would seem just the right sort for the job, incidentally, but his name is rarely mentioned in dispatches perhaps because, as a patriotic Scot, he is reckoned unlikely to countenance an offer. But you never know until you ask.

Crozier's ultimate problem, though, is that the queue of calibre candidates lining up to work for the FA is unlikely to stretch round the block, particularly since virtually every serious choice - Terry Venables, Bobby Robson, Peter Taylor, Arsène Wenger - has been snubbed, spurned or treated high-handedly by Lancaster Gate in the past. At least now the former advertising executive knows where he stands.

Only if he and his team of wise men (plus Wilkinson) achieve the right appointment, can we be sure that the FA has not simply swapped the pompous ossification of the past for a new regime of meretricious marketing speak.

Brown would seem just the right sort for the job, incidentally, but his name is rarely mentioned in dispatches perhaps because, as a patriotic Scot, he is reckoned unlikely to countenance an offer. But you never know until you ask. Crozier's ultimate problem, though, is that the queue of calibre candidates lining up to work for the FA is unlikely to stretch round the block, particularly since virtually every serious choice - Terry Venables, Bobby Robson, Peter Taylor, Arsène Wenger - has been snubbed, spurned or treated high-handedly by Lancaster Gate in the past. At least now the former advertising executive knows where he stands. Only if he and his team of wise men (plus Wilkinson) achieve the right appointment, can we be sure that the FA has not simply swapped the pompous ossification of the past for a new regime of meretricious marketing speak.

webTitle: Taylor flying high and fearless

fields.headline: Taylor flying high and fearless
fields.standfirst: Jon Brodkin meets the manager of the leaders preparing to face the champions
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor peers across his office at Leicester's training ground and smiles. "I can't believe I'm going to wake up on Saturday morning," he says, "and be managing a team playing Manchester United." He might have said lowly, second-placed Manchester United but, even as manager of the Premiership's top club, Taylor is too modest and polite.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor peers across his office at Leicester's training ground and smiles. "I can't believe I'm going to wake up on Saturday morning," he says, "and be managing a team playing Manchester United." He might have said lowly, second-placed Manchester United but, even as manager of the Premiership's top club, Taylor is too modest and polite.

His sense of excitement and incredulity is understandable. In May 1996, when Sir Alex Ferguson was celebrating another Double, Taylor had just guided Dover to 20th in the Vauxhall Conference. Nor has Taylor forgotten his first taste of Ferguson a few months later when he was coaching England's Under-21s. He was cowering behind his desk even before a Scottish voice answered the phone in a way which told him to forget any chit-chat.

"I was frightened out of my life to make the call," Taylor recalls. "And when Alex answered he must have had a bad day because he had the raving hump. I was only ringing to do him a favour. I thought Nicky Butt had an injury which meant he would want me to rest him."

This afternoon at Filbert Street there will be no favours from Taylor and no complaints if Ferguson has the raving hump. Leicester begin with a one-point advantage, and the flood of letters Taylor has received since the club went top suggests his postman - like Howard Wilkinson - must be suffering with a bad side.

Ferguson was not among the admiring scribes but Taylor does not tremble at the thought of him now. When he was deposed as under-21 coach 16 months ago Ferguson was among the first to phone to say how much United's players had enjoyed working with him. And might Ferguson regret twice inviting Taylor to training during his stint with England?

"I learned lots of little things about how he wanted training done," Taylor says. "The first time I happened to be staying at a hotel where Sir Alex was going to the gym that night. As I came away from the gym he drove up in his nice car and tooted. For me it was very brave but I asked whether he fancied a drink later.

"We had a good hour talking away, which was tremendous. I spoke to him about his training and what a good tempo it was. And he shared some experiences he'd had at Aberdeen and United, talking about certain players. To me he does it right. He has a very straight manner."

Those who have worked under Taylor say he has a similar style, as Stan Collymore found out. And the 47-year-old has not arrived at the top by accident. He starting coaching at 17 when, as a Southend winger, he formed a team comprising his mates at the local youth club.

"We went through the divisions very quickly, won the leagues and cups," Taylor recalls. "I've planned all my life to be a coach. There was never a time I wasn't managing a Sunday team until I got my first Saturday club, which was Dartford in 1986. I've used so many bits of paper writing down different teams, it used to drive my wife mad."

For a man who played for Crystal Palace, Tottenham and England, that was some commitment. Not all the jobs have been glamorous or successful - he was sacked by Southend in 1995 - but each has moulded a coach so highly respected that he would be many people's choice as England manager.

Ultimately that is his ambition. During his time at Lancaster Gate he studied Glenn Hoddle's press conferences and listened to his tactics as part of his preparation. But at this stage he rules himself out.

"It doesn't frighten me in terms of the types of football you face," he says. "I'm confident I can handle that but I feel to leave after four months at Leicester would be letting them down badly."

Taylor will feel let down if Kevin Keegan's successor is not English. He supports the idea of grooming coaches within the FA but stresses no one could step into the top job without extensive club experience. The ideal, he accepts, could be to have emerging managers working part-time with England.

"If you had just done the younger levels with England I'm sure you could go as far as the under-21s," he says. "But it's very different from dealing with the really powerful players and the pressure. It's also not just about coaching. Doing a session with England is easy because you've got the best players and the best facilities. It's the selection and the tactics that make it a hard job."

Taylor, of course, has made the Leicester job look easy since arriving in June. As in his previous post at Gillingham, where he won promotion from the Second Division at the first attempt, he has inherited a strong set-up rather than a crisis.

But that should not detract from his sensible policy of tinkering rather than overhauling. He is far more of a tracksuit manager than his predecessor Martin O'Neill and the enjoyment he gleans from coaching is obvious.

Just as Taylor's under-21s won six European Championship qualifiers without conceding a goal, Leicester have gone top with their defence breached only twice. The worry for Taylor, September's manager of the month, is that his side have scored only seven times.

"That goes back to the frustrating thing with Stan," he says, "because I signed Ade [Akinbiyi] to play alongside him. Stan is potentially the best centre-forward in England receiving the ball with his back to goal and I wanted Ade making forward runs. Now I've had to change it."

Taylor's treatment of the under-performing Collymore showed the hard side of a man who admits his biggest problem can be that he gets too close to his squad.

"The way he handles players stands out," says Andy Hessenthaler, the Gillingham manager who spent time with Taylor at Dartford, Watford and Gillingham. "He recognises you can't treat players the same and his coaching's brilliant. He had something different every day and it was so interesting you wanted to come in. Peter's serious when he has to be but he loves a laugh and a joke."

At the moment there is laughter aplenty but Taylor is not checking out potential Champions League opponents yet. He might if, at 4.45pm, Ferguson has the raving hump.

webTitle: Thome enjoying light life

fields.headline: Thome enjoying light life
fields.standfirst: Dominic Fifield hears from the Brazilian stopper keen to renew old acquaintances
fields.trailText: As they emerge from the tunnel today, fireworks exploding overhead and Prokofiev blazing in their ears, the Chelsea defenders could be forgiven if they suffer flashbacks to their last, humbling trip to Sunderland 10 months ago.
fields.body:
As they emerge from the tunnel today, fireworks exploding overhead and Prokofiev blazing in their ears, the Chelsea defenders could be forgiven if they suffer flashbacks to their last, humbling trip to Sunderland 10 months ago.

On that bitterly cold December afternoon, the Londoners' championship credentials were blown apart as Niall Quinn and Kevin Phillips ran riot on Wearside. By half-time, Gianluca Vialli's side had shipped four goals - the same number their hosts had conceded at Stamford Bridge on the season's opening day - as Chelsea players grappled pathetically in the dark at the Stadium of Light. For Sunderland, revenge was sweet.

This afternoon, once the smoke has cleared and the din subsided, Claudio Ranieri's side will find at least one familiar and not entirely hostile face awaiting them. Emerson Thome, Sunderland's Brazilian defender, will line up against his former team-mates aiming to prove a point. "They know it'll be tough," he smiles. "People like Albert [Ferrer] and Gus [Poyet] are my friends and I want them to do well - but not until after Saturday."

That Thome is playing against, rather than for, Chelsea is bizarre enough. It was the Londoners' eye-catching embarrassment at the Stadium of Light last year and a subsequent home defeat to Leeds that prompted Vialli to buy the 28-year-old from Sheffield Wednesday for £2.7m 10 months ago.

But any thought that his signing was a knee-jerk reaction to those losses was quickly dispelled by a series of impressive defensive displays, earning him a regular place at the heart of Chelsea's defence. Indeed, he did not taste Premiership defeat until returning to Hillsborough for his 16th appearance.

With such form behind him, it was somewhat surprising that Thome found himself out of favour with Vialli this season. He started one top-flight game for the Londoners - the ignominious 2-0 defeat at Bradford in August - before swapping the King's Road for the Quayside, the yuppie pads for the "howay the lads" in a club record £4.5m deal.

"I was not looking for a move," he says. "Chelsea is a massive club and they could be one of the great teams in England over the next few years. It would have been good to be a part of that.

"But there are a lot of quality players there. I just wanted to play football and Vialli could not offer me the chance to be a first-team regular. I think Chelsea already had a change in management in mind, but that was why I left and I don't regret my decision."

Other theories abounded. This afternoon Thome is charged with keeping Chelsea's former Boavista and Leeds striker Jimmy-Floyd Hasselbaink under wraps - a task he has relished whether in Portugal with Benfica or in Yorkshire with Wednesday. During the Brazilian's last days at Chelsea rumour had it that the pair had clashed in training, provoking Thome's abrupt departure. The Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson dismissed the incident as "just a scuffle", reiterating: "The only reason Thome left Chelsea was because he was very frustrated at not getting a first-team opportunity."

"I've played against Jimmy twice before," says the defender. "He's not the most skilful player ever, but he's strong and he can shoot from wherever. We have to be careful with him, but I'm looking forward to it."

"Emerson only had a short time at Chelsea but I know he's still got friends down there. He'll be up for the game and be anxious to do as well as he can," said Thome's new manager Peter Reid.

Since settling on Wearside, Thome's form has not been helped by Sunderland's shaky start to the new season. But, after five matches unbeaten and a first Premiership clean sheet since he arrived, against Leicester, the Brazilian is steadily making his presence felt. He has even taken the £3.5m Argentine midfielder Julio Arca under his wing, acting as an interpreter for the 19-year-old.

"The first few games with a new club are never easy. You've got to find your feet and adjust to how the team plays," he says. "It takes time to introduce yourself to the squad and to work out what is needed to improve things - that's why I was brought here.

"But I've started to feel a part of it and feel more comfortable and I think it has shown in my performances. The last few games have been better and I'm happy with that. As a defender, if we don't concede a goal I get a lot of pleasure. Of course, I want to win but when the game against Leicester ended goalless I felt a lot of satisfaction when I walked off."

A repeat of last season's emphatic result this afternoon would cheer both Thome and Reid, although the latter would settle for "an entertaining, scrambled 1-0 win in the last minute". Such a scenario would suit Thome as well.

"This is a match I'm really looking forward to," he adds. "It surprises me a bit that Chelsea are not higher in the table, but they did very well against Liverpool recently and I just hope they are not getting things together under the new manager.

"They were not in the best shape before the Liverpool game so maybe that win was a one-off. No one wants to lose a game, especially when it's against your old club, and I'm hoping everyone here has a good day. I'll be sure to let them know it's important beforehand."

webTitle: Wenger prepares to sue the FA

fields.headline: Wenger prepares to sue the FA
fields.trailText: Having dealt the Football Association one blow by ruling himself out of the England job, Arsène Wenger is ready to go for the knockout.
fields.body:
Having dealt the Football Association one blow by ruling himself out of the England job, Arsène Wenger is ready to go for the knockout.

The Arsenal manager is prepared to take the FA to court if his appeal against a 12-match suspension and £100,000 fine is rejected.

Wenger feels the punishment he received for an incident involving the fourth official Paul Taylor at Sunderland was unjust. He said: "I will first appeal. If that doesn't work I may have to go to a legal court. I will consider it with a lawyer.

"It is unacceptable that for 12 games I cannot work as I have always done. It will be difficult for me to sit in the stand because I have tried it many times and I have quite a problem with separation from my team."

Wenger was found guilty of holding Taylor in the tunnel, where tension was high after Patrick Vieira's late dismissal for striking Sunderland's Darren Williams. He insists he had to intervene to prevent a far worse incident involving Williams and Thierry Henry.

"When I heard the sanctions I couldn't believe it," Wenger added. "I feel like I have killed someone. They judged the situation to the letter of the law and didn't look at what intention was involved. My intention was never to hit anybody or insult anybody. I didn't even insult anybody. I just behaved as I think I had to."

The FA will try to hear the appeal before Wenger's suspension starts on October 30. His punishment was the minimum laid down in the FA's new disciplinary guidelines.

One specialist sports lawyer explained what Wenger might try to prove in court if his appeal fails. "What Arsenal's argument could include is allegations of restraint of trade and arguments over the disproportionality of the punishment because the FA's guidelines do not appear to allow the particular facts and circumstances of a case to be taken into consideration," explained Darren Bailey of the law firm Townleys.

Wenger feels the FA has been one-eyed in accepting the evidence presented to its disciplinary commission by Taylor. "They listen to their officials and nobody else," he said. "It's like when you go against the police."

Henry has claimed he was pushed by Taylor and that his manager intervened only to keep everyone apart, but Wenger does not plan to involve his squad in the appeal.

Reiterating that he intends to see out his contract with Arsenal until 2002, Wenger scotched talk of reaching an agreement with the FA to take over the England job in two years, though he did not rule out taking the post in future.

webTitle: TV farce may be repeated in June

fields.headline: TV farce may be repeated in June
fields.trailText: Despite the Football Association's best intentions, there is no guarantee that the fiasco of u>direct's pay-per-view coverage of the England v Finland match will not be repeated for the World Cup qualifier in Greece next summer.
fields.body:
Despite the Football Association's best intentions, there is no guarantee that the fiasco of u>direct's pay-per-view coverage of the England v Finland match will not be repeated for the World Cup qualifier in Greece next summer.

The match in Helsinki was the first England game to be shown on pay-per-view.

After many would-be viewers who had paid up to £9.99 were unable to see England's labours, the FA's Adrian Bevington said: "We would obviously do anything that we could to encourage them to get the game to as wide an audience as possible. But the home nation has control of the rights."

The rights for the Greece match in June have not yet been sold, although England's game in Albania on March 28 will be screened on Channel 5.

Sky, who have the rights to England's forthcoming home games and the return with Germany in September, have said they would not be interested in showing the Greece game on a pay-per-view basis.

From next season, all England's competitive home internationals will be shown live on free-to-air terrestrial television. Under the next television contract they will be screened simultaneously by Sky and the BBC.

webTitle: Small mercies please Little

fields.headline: Small mercies please Little
fields.standfirst: The Hull manager is happy out of the limelight - and England frame
fields.trailText: The man once tipped to succeed Terry Venables as England coach is sitting at his desk at Hull City's Boothferry Park, content not to be in contention this time. "People ask 'Whatever happened to Brian Little? He used to be good but he's clearly not any more,'" he says, smiling. "Well, here I am and I'm pretty happy, actually."
fields.body:
The man once tipped to succeed Terry Venables as England coach is sitting at his desk at Hull City's Boothferry Park, content not to be in contention this time. "People ask 'Whatever happened to Brian Little? He used to be good but he's clearly not any more,'" he says, smiling. "Well, here I am and I'm pretty happy, actually."

When Venables stepped down after Euro 96 the bookies had the then Aston Villa manager rivalling Bryan Robson, Ray Wilkins and Glenn Hoddle for the job. Now even the most optimistic punter would scoff at a flutter on him to replace Kevin Keegan. This afternoon Little will be too busy concentrating on taking Hull to the league's bottom club, Halifax Town, to contemplate his plummet out of the limelight.

"I remember all the speculation, but of course I was tipped to become England coach," he says. "I was at Villa, we'd finished fourth in the Premiership, we'd won the Coca-Cola Cup and got to the semi-final of the FA Cup. I was an up-and-coming English manager doing well. Some people think I must be mad to have walked away from all that; I could have made a lot of money. But I'm not unhappy doing what I'm doing."

A chart of Little's managerial career shows a startling progression and descent through the leagues - from relegation to the Conference with Darlington, and then winning it the next year followed immediately by the old Fourth Division championship, to promotion to the Premiership with Leicester City. Silverware at Aston Villa, the club where he made his name as a player, preceded his decline via Stoke City and West Bromwich Albion.

"I probably view management in a different way to others," he says. "I've been at the top, the bottom and the middle; I've been everywhere. As long as I get out of bed in the morning wanting to do it, that's fine."

Little has the pedigree to succeed - his record at Villa Park was impressive with fourth- and fifth-place finishes in the Premiership in his two full years in charge. A sluggish start to the 1997-98 league campaign culminated in his resignation in February, but only after he had seen Villa through to a Uefa Cup quarter-final against Atletico Madrid.

"It was my choice to leave Villa and I have no regrets," he says. "That was a fantastic job for me and I thought I did well there but I needed a breather from football. Management at the top level is the hardest because of the high profile and I genuinely needed a break. But that's not to say I wouldn't try it again."

After limited success at Stoke there was disappointment at West Bromwich, prompting his dismissal midway through last season - "I didn't do very well but I sensed they didn't want me there" - before he turned up at Hull in April.

"Most people wouldn't take jobs like this but I thought the club had potential," he says, although Hull are more a comatose than a sleeping giant. The largest port in Europe never to host top-flight football has seen its side settle in the basement and, with as much turmoil in the boardroom as on the pitch, City were almost wound up last summer.

Barely two weeks into the job Little found the club had been locked out of their stadium by the former owner David Lloyd, while plans for team building were left in tatters by a transfer embargo.

"The summer was a big shock for me," he says. "The club was closed down when Mr Lloyd didn't receive the rent on Boothferry Park. We couldn't pay the wages and had to borrow money off the Professional Footballers' Association. We still need our home games to operate as we have no money and we won't have an opportunity to sign new players until next summer."

Lloyd, who described the city of Hull as "crap" and its citizens as "living in the dark ages" when he sold the club in No vember 1998, is willing to sell the ground to the current board for £1.35m, but is also negotiating with two other parties. The chairman Nick Buchanan is also talking to the council over a possible £34m, 25,000 all-seat stadium in the city.

Little concedes that it will be some time before City can come close to fulfilling their potential. "Everybody keeps telling me Hull is the seventh largest city in the country but we can't think about going too quickly too soon. Fittingly Little's opposite number this afternoon will be the former Fulham manager Paul Bracewell, more used to the good life at Craven Cottage. As their teams take to the pitch both might be forgiven for wondering where it all went wrong. Little, for his part, is unconvinced it has.

"I know it's all a far cry from Aston Villa in the Premiership but I'm still educating myself in management. There is a light at the end of this tunnel."

webTitle: Sauzee earns raves for his Edinburgh encore

fields.headline: Sauzee earns raves for his Edinburgh encore
fields.trailText: A big Frenchman is currently the toast of Edinburgh. With his permanently smiling face, sticking out ears, and feet the size of large baguettes, Franck Sauzée is the talisman of reborn Hibernian. Today Hibernian and Sauzée play arguably one of the most significant games in years at Easter Road, when Rangers visit in the Scottish Premier League.
fields.body:
A big Frenchman is currently the toast of Edinburgh. With his permanently smiling face, sticking out ears, and feet the size of large baguettes, Franck Sauzée is the talisman of reborn Hibernian. Today Hibernian and Sauzée play arguably one of the most significant games in years at Easter Road, when Rangers visit in the Scottish Premier League.

Hibs, sitting second in the table, are a point ahead of Rangers, who lie third. The Glasgow club have played one match fewer but the psychology of their supremacy is still not lost on Hibs. A win or a draw today would preserve rare oneupmanship over Rangers. If any faint traces are to remain about Scottish clubs holding the Old Firm in check, Hibs need to take a point or points to add conviction to their valour.

If Alex McLeish, who sat at Alex Ferguson's feet at Aberdeen, is the main source of Hibs' revival, Sauzée is certainly its imprint on the park. The man who won 39 caps for France - it would have been much more had he not fallen out with Gérard Houllier - is marauding through matches in Hibs' famous green and white, spraying passes around from his new position as a libero.

"I can hardly believe the way Franck is playing these days," says David Zitelli, Hibs' other Frenchman. "He is the new Beckenbauer."

Sauzée is a rare footballer, who has seen everything and done it all yet still bounds through games excitedly. He will be 35 two weeks from today but exhibits the thrill of a child whenever things are going right on the park. Two weeks ago, having poked a free-kick around St Johnstone's wall to score in the less than intoxicating setting of McDiarmid Park, he ran the length of the field in celebration of his feat. For a man who won the European Cup with Marseille in 1993, this seemed bewildering.

"I'm happy with my football these days and I'm proud to be the captain of Hibs," says Sauzée. "At my age, at this stage of my life, I wouldn't still be playing unless I was content within myself."

When he signed for Hibs in October 1999, Sauzée agreed to play for a year. Now he is into his second season, and it looks like he will stay for a third.

Today he resembles an old warhorse who plays with a certain Gallic flair, but the vestiges of the old Sauzée are still very evident. Tall, elegant, with an appetite for the biting tackle, he was a forceful presence in French international teams through a period of the late 1980s and early 1990s, when that team did not otherwise fulfil its rich potential.

At club level Sauzée has been the happy vagrant. After learning his craft with Sochaux, he moved, still aged only 23, to Marseille, but this first spell with his home-town team was to prove stormy. From Marseille it was along the Cte d'Azur to Monaco in 1990, then back to Marseille for two seasons in 1991, before Serie A and Atalanta Bergamo beckoned in 1993.

His dainty feet were employed by Strasbourg and Montpellier before Hibs' siren call 18 months ago. After a stirring decade of action, Sauzée has found contentment in Scotland's capital.

His first match in the biting atmosphere north of the border could not have been less alluring - against Falkirk at crumbling Brockville Park. "I remember playing in that match and maybe having 10 touches of the ball in total - the play just went on above my head," says Sauzée. "But coming to Hibs has been a great move for me. Alex McLeish is a good coach and Edinburgh is a fantastic city."

Zitelli, whom McLeish signed in August as a brother-in-arms for Sauzée, describes his compatriot as "a changed man" since being unleashed on the Scottish game. "He has opened up, has flourished and is making the most of life," says Zitelli. "And he is still capable of impressing on the pitch."

Last season, in an horrific incident, Sauzée lost three front teeth in a prang on the pitch. His new dental work is not the only patched-up aspect of this thrillingly restored footballer.

webTitle: Rangers strike deal for £11m-rated Tamudo

fields.headline: Rangers strike deal for £11m-rated Tamudo
fields.trailText: Rangers and Español have agreed terms for the transfer of the £11m-rated striker Raul Tamudo to Ibrox.
fields.body:
Rangers and Español have agreed terms for the transfer of the £11m-rated striker Raul Tamudo to Ibrox.

The two clubs were reported to be embroiled in a disagreement over the way the fee would be paid in light of possible changes to the transfer ruling but the Scottish champions confirmed yesterday that the two clubs have now reached a satisfactory arrangement.

"Rangers and Español have agreed terms subject to changes in the transfer system, which is currently under review," said a statement from the Glasgow club.

The St Johnstone manager Sandy Clark has signed the young Reading midfielder Sean Evers on a three-month deal and the 23-year-old looks set to be involved at some stage against Motherwell at Fir Park today.

The midfielder signed for Reading from Luton in a deal worth £500,000 but he has impressed Clark during his loan spell at McDiarmid Park and will now remain in Perth until the end of the year.

BBC Scotland will screen both legs of Celtic's Uefa Cup tie with Bordeaux live on October 26 and November 9. The BBC will have four live games in a 2-week period, including the Premier League games involving St Johnstone and Rangers, on October 22, and Kilmarnock against Celtic, on November 5.

A two-week stoppage of Greek domestic football will have no impact on Champions League fixtures involving the two Greek teams involved, Panathinaikos and Olympiakos said yesterday.

The matches between Panathinaikos and Germany's Hamburg on Wednesday in Athens in Group E and Olympiakos Piraeus and Heerenveen on Tuesday in the Netherlands in Group C will go ahead despite the Greek Football Association's decision to cancel all domestic matches for two weeks after a row with the national sports ministry on Thursday.

The Cheltenham manager Steve Cotterill has signed a two-year extension to his contract with the Third Division side after rejecting the chance to become Oxford's new coach this week.

Cotterill twice held talks with the Oxford chairman Firoz Kassam about becoming the new manager at the Manor Ground following Denis Smith's resignation at the start of last week. But the 36-year-old, who still had 18 months left on his contract with Cheltenham, has now signed a new two-year deal which will keep him at Whaddon Road until June 2004 after taking his side to second place in the Third Division in only their second year in the Football League.

The Cheltenham chairman Paul Baker said: "We have a good working relationship and the team are doing well. It's brilliant news for us although one day we realise it will be time for Steve to move on."

webTitle: Players union pulls out of transfer talks

fields.headline: Players union pulls out of transfer talks
fields.trailText: The international players' union FIFPro announced after a meeting with the European Union competition chief Mario Monti it would have nothing more to to with the task force set up to hammer out proposals to revamp the game's transfer rules until it took players' demands seriously.
fields.body:
The international players' union FIFPro announced after a meeting with the European Union competition chief Mario Monti it would have nothing more to to with the task force set up to hammer out proposals to revamp the game's transfer rules until it took players' demands seriously.

"Fifa and the leagues want their education programmes for young players but they're not willing to do anything for 'normal' players over the age of 23," the FIFPro secretary general Theo van Seggelen said yesterday.

"We won't speak with the task force any more until they come to us with proposals that are acceptable. Mr Monti assured us the European Commission won't approve any proposal if we're not involved in it too."

Football's governing bodies set up the task force in an effort to prevent Monti outlawing the current transfer system, which he says breaks European rules on fair competition and abuses workers' rights to freedom of movement. They say banning the current system would throw the game into chaos but, under pressure from the Commission, have pledged to come up with proposals by the end of October to prevent the transfer system being banned.

Van Seggelen, who met Monti with the FIFPro President Gordon Taylor and a delegation of players from around Europe, said fears of chaos were exaggerated. "We don't think anything much will happen to football under a new system. Changes won't influence the game much," he said.

Fifa has suggested allowing the free movement of players over the age of 24 and ending transfers for players under the age of under-18-year-olds 18, but said clubs should be able to seek compensation for the transfer of players of between 18 and 24.

FIFPro, however, believe the plans would discriminate against older players. "We want to clarify the situation for players of over 23, as to whether they have the possibility to break their contracts. The trouble is that the clubs still think they can make money from the trade in players," Van Seggelen said. He said the unions backed the idea of "transfer windows" - or limited periods during the year when players could move.

Monti's office said in a statement that FIFPro had expressed its disappointment at the lack of progress made by the task force and that the players said they were willing to go to court if their concerns were not taken into account.

"I hope that Fifa, Uefa, the leagues, the clubs and the players will make all efforts possible to arrive at a solution which preserves the specificity of sport while respecting national legislation on contracts, the free circulation of players and EU law," the statement quoted Monti as saying.

webTitle: Parlour referee calls for video replays

fields.headline: Parlour referee calls for video replays
fields.trailText: Alain Sars, the French referee who has been the subject of bleating criticism in the English press since the goalless draw with Finland in Helsinki on Wednesday, has asked for video replays to be introduced in football.
fields.body:
Alain Sars, the French referee who has been the subject of bleating criticism in the English press since the goalless draw with Finland in Helsinki on Wednesday, has asked for video replays to be introduced in football.

Sars was called to account over two incidents that England followers felt deprived Howard Wilkinson's team of a World Cup qualifying win they scarcely deserved for an abject performance.

The first was the decision to show the Finnish goalkeeper Antti Niemi only a yellow card for a last-ditch foul on Teddy Sheringham outside the box; the second was when Sars and his linesman failed to award a goal after Ray Parlour's shot three minutes from time bounced down off the crossbar.

Television replays indicated that the ball had landed over the goalline, sparking much English breast-beating about 1966 and all that. But Sars, an experienced official, told the French sports paper L'Equipe: "How do you think an assistant can see where the ball bounced when it's just hit the crossbar at 100mph and comes out straight away?

"My assistant Pierre Ufrasi couldn't be on the goalline, he was on the last defender's line. People who are now criticising were in front of their television, and that is really bad luck for us. We needed the video, we've been asking for it, in vain."

England were also angry that the Hearts goalkeeper Niemi was not sent off following the earlier incident after five minutes involving Sheringham, who looked to be ideally placed to open the scoring. But again Sars defended himself vigorously.

"In such a case a referee wonders if that player really had a chance to score," he said. "However, I saw two Finnish defenders who could have intercepted the ball if Sheringham had shot. I assessed the striker had been tripped and that the keeper deserved a yellow card.

"I certainly thought that the England striker had been knocked off balance. I felt it was a foul that deserved a yellow card, and I didn't think there had been any play-acting.

"But I really don't understand these reactions, especially when the players came to shake our hands at the end of the game.

"It is so important nowadays for a country to qualify for the World Cup that they need to blame someone when things are going wrong, and the referees are usually the easiest targets. I don't feel responsible for England's defeat [sic] at all and anyway they had only one real opportunity to score."

Everton won the right to bring the Israeli winger Idan Tal into the Premiership when his work permit was finally granted yesterday. Tal's arrival will end a six-month chase for the Maccabi Petah Tikva player, whose first application for a permit was rejected by the Department of Employment.

Both Tal and the Hearts defender Gary Naysmith will be Everton players by the start of next week, while Richard Dunne is about to play his last game for the club before an expected £3m move to either Manchester City or Charlton Athletic.

The three deals will bring the total of players bought and sold by the manager Walter Smith during his 28-month reign at Goodison to 60. Smith's spending will pass the £50m mark, while the money for Dunne will mean that Smith has been forced to bring in £42.65m in that time to balance the books.

Smith's spending will pass the £50m mark, while the money for Dunne will mean that Smith has been forced to bring in £42.65m in that time to balance the books.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Just one more strange day in the very strange career of Michael Knighton, who faces a red-card demonstration today from Carlisle fans keen to see the back of him.
fields.body:
Just one more strange day in the very strange career of Michael Knighton, who faces a red-card demonstration today from Carlisle fans keen to see the back of him.

Last month Knighton was banned from being a director of any company after a DTI investigation into a school in Huddersfield owned by Knighton that went into liquidation, but he remains in control of the club, thanks to his 93% shareholding in the holding company.

One surprising ally of the fans is Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson, who did time at Brunton Park in the early 80s and still has shares in the club. "For the sake of the club, Michael Knighton should hand it over to people who are prepared to invest in it," Hutchinson said. "Local people trusted by the fans should be in charge. It should be a community club."

Quite right too, though it's not a concept he has been noticeably attached to at Chelsea.

A disappointingly thin turn-out of football folk at Reggie Kray's funeral on Wednesday, with only David Webb and Alan Curbishley's brother holding the fort. However, Paul Gascoigne seems to have learned something from the lovable East End mobsters, if his theory of getting the best out of England's youngsters is any guide. "I would like to hammer our kids. Bring them on nicely, but show them respect." Hammer? Respect? It might have come straight out of the twins' own coaching manual.

Some of David O'Leary's "babies" may enjoy life in the fast lane, but Matthew Jones is not among them. The South Wales Echo reports that Jones's idea of a good night out does not involve the usual temptations open to young men with plenty of money. "When my gran comes up we all go to the local bingo hall in one big group," Jones said. "In fact I have become a member of the bingo hall. That's what my gran and my family would do back home in Llanelli, so why not in Leeds?" Don Revie would have approved.

One of the founding myths of English football, "the Russian linesman", has had a solid airing this week after Ray Parlour's misfortune in Helsinki. And it is a myth, of course, created in those far-off days when everyone from the Soviet Union was Russian. It's far too late to change his fate now, but the linesman was Azerbaijani, as anyone who has been to the Tofik Bakhramov Stadium in Baku can testify.

Usually reliable TV watchers report an extraordinary exchange on Sky this week. Commenting on the possibility of Terry Venables taking over from Kevin Keegan, a respected broadsheet journalist is said to have remarked that his reappointment would be vetoed by the chairman of the FA's international committee, Noel White, whom he described as "the nigger in the woodpile". Surely it can't be true.

Not for the first time this season, the Scottish Premier League has shown a wanton disrespect for tradition and the needs of disoriented travelling fans. Once again, all five matches this weekend kick off at the absurd time of three o'clock on a Saturday afternoon.

In this week's release from the Ryman League, Premier Division Gravesend & Northfleet announce the availability of their 20-year-old striker Dexley Fidyk. In the limited space provided, all the club could say is that Dexley "has an excellent attitude and lives in SW London". How refreshing it would be if bigger clubs had to sell their players using the same brutal shorthand of the small ads columns. How confident would they be of getting rid of the likes of Stan Collymore ("unwanted gift"), Paul Gascoigne ("needs some work") or Tore Andre Flo ("hardly used")?

No doubt Peter Taylor will enjoy the traditional magnum of champagne (not to mention the traditional losing streak) after being voted manager of the month for September. In South Africa, however, they have no truck with such pretentious nonsense. Bruce Grobbelaar, now in charge of Pretoria's SuperSport United, has just received the equivalent award, which entitled him to 72 cases of beer.

mike.ticher@theguardian.com

webTitle: A job that turned into a lottery with no punters

fields.headline: A job that turned into a lottery with no punters
fields.trailText: Should anyone ever take on the job of coaching the England football team, the new man must be ready for the flak that goes with the job.
fields.body:
All this week it has been difficult to stop a couple of lines from a Danny Kaye film, The Court Jester, running through the mind:

The pellet with the poison's in the chalice from the palace.

The flagon with the dragon has the brew that is true.

Kaye was a weakling in a suit of armour about to fight a knight twice his size, so the opponent had to be doped. Should anyone ever take on the job of coaching the England football team, the new man might be advised to hire a video of The Court Jester to pick up some tips, the opponent in this case being the job and all the aggro that goes with it.

Before England galumphed to a scoreless draw in Finland on Wednesday their caretaker, Howard Wilkinson, insisted that, far from being a poisoned chalice, the job would be a golden goblet for the right person. Having taken a couple of sips from the cup of hemlock in Helsinki he may wish he had opted for the flagon with the dragon.

After the game Wilkinson echoed a thought similar to one expressed by Adam Crozier, the Football Association's chief executive, when he implied that it might be more sensible to build a team for the 2004 European Championship and 2006 World Cup rather concentrating purely on Japan and Korea in two years' time.

Unfortunately Wilkinson used the phrase "abandoning the World Cup" which triggered off accusations on the back pages of surrender and wimping out when all he had meant was that the next England coach might regard the 2002 World Cup as a means to an end rather than an end in itself.

When Wilkinson first became England's caretaker coach, following the sacking of Glenn Hoddle, he said that, if the FA wanted a successful national team, "then it must put the structure in place which will protect the coach and give him the best support". He added that in choosing Hoddle's successor the FA "should know a little bit more about people they're considering than what they read in the papers or what someone tells them".

So impressed were those making the appointment that they signed up Kevin Keegan largely because the Sun said they should. Only now, under Crozier, does the FA appear to be taking Wilkinson's points to heart.

Whoever England's next coach turns out to be it must be hoped that this time the structure for building regularly successful international teams includes a dynastic system which will produce a ready-made successor instead of the present crazy lottery for which none of the more likely names wants to buy a ticket.

Ron Greenwood inaugurated such a system when he managed England between 1977 and 1982, creating a chain of command for the senior team, the Under-21s and those below. It is no accident that the smoothest transition of power from one England coach to another followed Greenwood's retirement after the 1982 World Cup when he handed over to Bobby Robson, who was already part of the set-up.

The FA made one of its bigger mistakes when Greenwood was not asked to stay on in an advisory capacity. As Wilkinson has observed, when people leave the England job "they take their experience away either in their heads or in cardboard boxes". Or in Keegan's case a matchbox.

If Crozier is true to his words, the FA ought to get it right now. But how easy would this be to apply in the case of a foreign coach, an idea which has steadily gained ground since Keegan's resignation following the defeat by Germany a week ago?

Bobby Charlton's objection, that to have a foreigner running the England team would be a disgrace and an insult, can be excused because Charlton represents a time in English football when the idea was not only unthinkable but unnecessary. England had the players and nobody was thinking beyond Alf Ramsey as manager.

The notion of having an Italian or a Frenchman in charge of England is a disgraceful reflection on the way that playing standards here have been allowed to wither for the sake of the quick fix of foreign imports while the coaching side has not so much been neglected as allowed to wear blinkers, oblivious to what was needed to keep up with trends abroad.

The practical difficulty of appointing a foreign coach is that he would want a back-up staff of compatriots, taking them with him when he left. The situation would be no different from last Sunday, when Wilkinson found himself having to scrape around for assistants because Keegan's coaches, Arthur Cox and Peter Beardsley, were not prepared to stay on even for three more days.

Objections to a foreign appointment on xenophobic grounds are not worth a first glance, let alone a second. But should this happen, it would still be a sad reversal of the days when English coaches like Vic Buckingham and, much more recently, Roy Hodgson were thriving abroad.

Few will probably remember George Raynor, the Yorkshireman who took Sweden to the 1958 World Cup final. "Perhaps I am regarded as a freak at home," Raynor wrote at the time. His recipe for budding footballers was: "Never let your skill make you big-headed, keep trying to play football whatever the provocations, and keep off drink and train hard."

There are some dressing rooms in the Premier League which would regard Raynor as a freak now.

webTitle: Cool companies

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: Inktomi
fields.trailText: Inktomi
fields.body:
Silicon Valley start-up Inktomi can claim much of the credit for keeping the internet running, despite periodic predictions of its imminent demise. Software developed by the San Mateo-based company has enabled many of the largest internet infrastructure and media companies to cope with the exponential growth in the number of internet users, web sites and network traffic.

Named after a Lakota Indian legend about a canny spider known for its ability to defeat larger adversaries, Inktomi is a classic California success story from the epicentre of the world wide web, mixing technological knowhow, entrepreneurial flair and the luck of being in the right place at the right time. The group's founders - Eric Brewer and Paul Gauthier -were working on a US government-funded project aimed at developing supercomputer power at microcomputer prices by clustering low-cost off-the-shelf workstations. To prove the scalability of their project, the two computer scientists looked for an application that would validate the technology. The test application they happened upon was the first internet search engine and the rest, as they say is history.

Today, Inktomi's software accounts for more than half of the market and its engine now powers many of the world's leading search sites, including AOL's, GeoCities, HotBot, NBC's Snap! and the Disney Internet Guide.

Inktomi fancies itself as the heart and soul of the world wide web (logo pictured left), from its "vantage point in the cockpit of the internet" - interfacing with all the major players on the web. Its mission is to build software applications that are crucial to the internet's infrastructure.

For the last couple of years Inktomi has been building bridgeheads in Europe via the mobile phone market - part of its broader ambition.

With the usual transatlantic optimism and immodesty which seems to characterise many Silicon Valley firms, current president, chief executive officer and chairman David Peterschmidt wants Inktomi's software to become the "ubiquitous translator" that allows web-based information to be delivered, in an intelligible format, to all kinds of internet-enabled devices from mobile phones to palm top computers.

The efforts to crack the mobile internet market, which are co-ordinated from its UK-based European headquarters, has led to the firm hiring technology-literate sales and marketing professionals. In return, Inktomi offers a culture that blends the financial stability of a blue-chip firm with the fun and fast moving entrepreneurial spirit of a start-up. Apart from share options and private health plans, new recruits get to spend three weeks in its San Fransisco training centre.

For online CV registration see Inktomi's European webpage www.inktomi.com/europe

webTitle: Help: I have opinions too, you know!

fields.headline: Help: I have opinions too, you know!
fields.standfirst: I've got a boss who says things like "you're paid to do, not to think" whenever I express an opinion. How can I convince him my ideas have some value?  RN, publications assistant, Reading
fields.trailText: I've got a boss who says things like "you're paid to do, not to think" whenever I express an opinion. How can I convince him my ideas have some value? RN, publications assistant, Reading
fields.body:
If your boss is unusual within the organisation, don't allow yourself to be riled. Treat his comments as a joke, tug your forelock and take your inspirations to someone senior to him. Never waste good ideas on people who don't have the wit to appreciate them.

Be aware that those who appear to ignore you are capable of stealing and recycling what they dismiss. It's naive to believe you will always receive credit for having thought of

something first, so before you share your flashes of brilliance weigh up the likelihood of getting a return for them. In a knowledge economy, ideas are

the most valuable of currencies. Employers who don't encourage and reward thoughtful creativity are not worth investing your time and ability in.

If your boss reflects the organisational culture, start looking for another job. Unless serfdom appeals, there's no long term future for intelligent

life forms in an organisation which condones his attitude. Chances are it's the sort of place where no one does much thinking, either because they're not capable or because they're too busy sorting out recurrent crises caused by their blustering management style.

A thinker would realise that this is not the best way of doing things and threaten the status quo. A future in an environment that operates on a system of mindlessly obeying orders doesn't bear thinking about.

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to using the right names at work

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to using the right names at work
fields.trailText: It's flattering when someone you've met briefly remembers your name, mortifying when the individual you thought you'd made an impression on gets it wrong.
fields.body:
A. Hey you

It's flattering when someone you've met briefly remembers your name, mortifying when the individual you thought you'd made an impression on gets it wrong.

Names and the way they are used can make you feel great or small. In most situations you don't even think about how you use people's names, you just do. But there's a curl-up-and-die feeling at those times when you forget a name. When in doubt, don't use a name at all.

B. In moderation

Much embarrassment can be avoided by forcing yourself to concentrate when first introduced. Make a conscious effort to remember names, but be wary of using word association techniques to jog your memory - the individual known as Dick may not see the funny side of being called Spotty or Clever. Feeling proud of yourself for having remembered who it is you're talking to is no justification for putting their name in every sentence. Such continual repetition doesn't make you sound sincere, just creepy.

C. Formal qualification

Knowing whether to use the first name of someone who is a stranger to you can be difficult, particularly if they out-rank you. Take your cue from how they introduce themselves. If unsure, err on the side of formality. Being invited to use first names is fine, but imagine someone you've been calling by their nickname saying "do call me Mr Jones". If you need to show that you scorn hierarchies and power play, stick to first names at all times - except job interviews.
