webTitle: Hit and miss record of graduate targeting

fields.headline: Hit and miss record of graduate targeting
fields.standfirst: Are you in your ideal employer's line of fire?
fields.trailText: Are you in your ideal employer's line of fire?
fields.body:
Graduate recruitment just isn't fair. It's all about selection and exclusion, and this begins a lot earlier than many students realise. Because no organisation can attend every careers fair at every university, each has to choose to visit the events most likely to provide the highest number of quality applicants.

This is called targeting, and although there are many factors involved, the main effect is that top companies tend to go to the "best" universities and miss out what they consider to be the weaker ones.

October and November see the first career fairs of the recruitment year and a look at which companies are going where reveals how targeting works.

The University of Bristol (sixth on the Financial Times league table of the UK's top universities) is holding two fairs, for engineering and science, and one for finance and IT. Of the top 25 organisations believed by students to offer the best opportunities for graduates (UK Graduate Careers Survey 1999), eight have confirmed their presence at the fairs, while a further eight will be giving presentations over the next few weeks.

In other words, at least 16 out of the top 25 organisations will be attending careers events at the University of Bristol. A 64% strike rate - not bad.

At the other end of the scale is Bournemouth University (97th and bottom in the FT table). It is holding one general autumn fair, and of the top 25 organisations, only three will be in attendance, while two more are giving presentations during the term. A strike rate of just 20% - not good.

The fact that Bristol can attract 16 top companies while Bournemouth can only muster five should not, however, be overstated. First, only students from top universities are asked to contribute their opinions to the UK Graduate Careers Survey which means that the popularity of an organisation depends mainly on how great a presence it has at the high-ranking universities. Secondly, despite its low position in the FT survey, Bournemouth is one of the best-rated universities for placing its students in graduate jobs.

These caveats aside, what targeting means is that Bristol students are going to be more aware of the top-notch opportunities and have more information about them than their peers at Bournemouth. By not visiting some universities, companies are in effect de-selecting applicants before the recruitment round even begins.

Jeff Goodman, director of the careers advisory service at the University of Bristol and vice president of the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services,

says: "Companies use targeting because it allows them to focus their resources in places which they perceive provide the best outcome for their investment. But when considering targeting it is important to remember that it is not just universities. Companies will also target specific courses. For example, some companies might like courses which include a year in industry and so institutions which run a lot of sandwich courses will benefit.

"The second point to make is that companies continue to use other methods of contacting students such as advertising so there is no sense that some students are excluded. However, it may be easier for students at the universities the companies target most to get a feel for the market."

The "feel for the market" not only includes information about opportunities, but also an understanding of what top companies are after. Even if you know that a company is recruiting, if you have never had the chance to talk to one of its graduate employees you have no model of the sort of profile they're looking for. How then can students from the less visited universities combat this deficit?

"The secret is forward planning," says Eric Whittington, head of careers at London Guildhall University (90th on the FT table). "Your commitment and interest must be manifest in your CV. This means starting as early as you can by networking with whatever resources are available to you, getting quality work experience, and if you can't do this then doing some work shadowing. It also means demonstrating skills like team-working through recognised extra-curricula activities. This can often be more important than UCAS points in determining whether you're chosen for interview. But you do need to think ahead."

"Targeting isn't a big problem because those companies don't provide our major source of graduate vacancies," says Pam Brooke, head of the careers service at Bournemouth University. webTitle: Entrepreneurs don't have to look like this - do they?

fields.headline: Entrepreneurs don't have to look like this - do they?
fields.standfirst: Inventive graduates urged to strike while the idea is hot
fields.trailText: Inventive graduates urged to strike while the idea is hot
fields.body:
Y ou don't have to be middle-aged and male to start your own business here - but it helps! The bumper stickers were the only things missing when, at an enterprise-boosting inititiave earlier this year, the government wheeled out the usual suspects like Alan Sugar, Richard Branson and Stelios Haji-Ioannou (pictured, right, with the PM).

Yet according to new research entrepreneurial spirit is flourishing among the under-25s. In a poll of 16 to 24-year olds by the BBC's Essentials website, half claim to want to start their own businesses in the future, and of these one in ten have ambitions to go solo within the next two years.

Being in control of their own destiny is an aspiration for 48% of respondents, while making more money appeals to just over a third of those about to make their first career choice. However existing research suggests that in Britain many graduates fail to follow through their intentions.

A study of 10 countries published last year by the London Business School and Babson College, in Boston, Massachusetts, found that one adult in 12 was trying to start a business in the US, compared with one in 30 in the UK. Only 16% of Britons thought there were good opportunities for a start-up in the short term, compared with 57 % in the US.

The key is confidence - in yourself and in your idea, says Mark Desvaux, a Swansea University graduate who has been starting businesses since the age of eight when he began selling tea to enthusiasts at his father's model aeroplane club. Other ventures included organising group ski-trips while on a student exchange to Canada.

After graduating with a degree in management science, Mark considered starting his own internet search engine business, but instead spent four years as a consultant with a big internet service provider before plucking up the courage to set up HouseWeb - an online property site - at the end of last year.

"I've often wondered what might have happened had I taken the plunge straight after university," he says. "I gained invaluable experience during my four years of employment and it's meant I've probably made fewer mistakes than I would have done. But if I had to advise a graduate who believes 100% their business idea will work, I'd say go for it. Just make sure that your idea is not a short-term hit, but that it's something which will continue to fascinate you for the next five or ten years. You're in this for the long-haul."

A good half-way house, suggests Mark is to take a job with a young start-up company, where graduates can learn the broad range of skills needed to establish a business. Trained advisers are available to answer work queries on the BBC's free Essentials phoneline 0808 100 8000, or via the Essentials website www.bbc.co.uk/essentials

webTitle: How to ... mix with clients without letting the side down

fields.headline: How to ... mix with clients without letting the side down
fields.standfirst: Avoid embarrasing gaffes by mirroring their behaviour
fields.trailText: Avoid embarrasing gaffes by mirroring their behaviour
fields.body:
If you're more accustomed to falling out of the pub at the end of the night than sipping champers at an art gallery, the thought of mixing with clients might not be your idea of a good time.

But since networking and relationships are increasingly important in the "new economy", it's more than likely that at some point you'll find "socialising" becomes part of your job spec. Author Neasa MacErlean says: "We're moving more and more towards a party age and we all have to pretend to be spontaneous and get on well naturally."

The trick is to not be intimidated by it all and, even if the wine is flowing, not to get carried away. Always remember that when you're with clients or suppliers, you're there on business, representing your own credibility and that of the company. There are plenty of tales of sorry graduates who had one drink too many and ended up red faced and hungover.

Problem is, there's no single way to play this game - you'll have to feel your way, even if that means more than one evening spent with a grin the cheshire cat would be proud of plastered across your face.

The key is to behave "appropriately" - but unfortunately that definition depends on the setting and the people.

Chris Evans has just moved to a customer support role that involves lots of client lunches and dinner parties. He says: "It's such an unnatural situation, not at all like being with your friends. Before I started I was told only to watch my alcohol consumption, so I had to wing it a bit for the first few times."

He advises mirroring the behaviour of your client when it comes to things like drinking smoking and coarse language.

Professor Cary Cooper, occupational psychologist, agrees: "Don't assume too much about the your clients and don't get too chummy-chummy - you'll come over like a used car salesman," he says. As relationships develop you can, he suggests, afford to be a little more relaxed. "The longer and closer the relationship the easier it becomes," he continues.

Sometimes you can use your inexperience to your advantage. If you admit that you don't know everything, or that you are in an unfamiliar situation, then most people will warm to your honesty be that at a large or small event.

That said, large gatherings register bigger readings on the shy-ometer than a small business lunch.

Rather than hiding in the toilets, try looking at noticeboards or hovering around a group of two people - chances are they'll include you in the end. If not, the simplest way is to find the party host, introduce yourself and ask them to introduce you to a few people. Remember also that at least some of the other people there will be on their own too and you can always team up with them.

If you're a smoker, go outside and strike up a conversation with the other smokers. There's always a smokers' camaraderie and it's difficult not to find some common ground when you're both struggling with a box of matches in a force 10 gale.

Male-orientated industries can be a particular problem if you are young, female and naive. Cooper says: "Be careful. Although there is always subtle sexuality in the workplace, the onus is on you, unfortunately, to make sure you don't come across in the wrong way."

After a while, though, you'll find yourself developing a relaxed client-facing personality. Anglo-Saxon hospitality still revolves around booze, so remember that while a couple of glasses for dutch courage is no bad thing, you should switch to soft drinks soon after.

MacErlean has her own opinions on party dynamics. She thinks that some hosts actually try to get their clients drunk in the hope of getting a good sales deal or, even worse, allowing them to embarrass themselves so that they feel they owe the host something. "It's all quite Machiavellian," she says.

If you don't remember anything else...

Much of this advice may seem obvious, but a straw poll of your friends and colleagues will reveal more than a few toe-curling stories that could have been easily prevented had the crucial "don't drink and talk" rule been observed.

But socialising with clients does get easier with time and close business relationships will pay dividends as you progress your career.

webTitle: Act of faith

fields.headline: Act of faith
fields.trailText: David Oyelowo: Actor
fields.body:
Name: David Oyelowo

status:Actor

Past: Studied at London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art. Landed two-month stint on BBC 2 drama Brothers and Sisters . Lead role in fringe production Suppliants earned him Ian Charleson Award nomination for best newcomer and work for the Royal Shakespeare Company. Completed Dog Eat Dog , a FilmFour production which co-stars All Saint's Melanie Blatt as his girlfriend.

Present: Lead role in Henry VI, opening in Stratford later this year. First black actor with RSC to portray an English king.

Strengths: "More of the same please. I've managed TV, theatre and film within two years of leaving drama school."

"I draw strength from being a Christian. The level of rejection that goes with this job can eat you up."

Weaknesses: "I get impatient. It took four months to hear if I had a part in Dog Eat Dog and I tied myself up in knots just waiting."

Wisdom: "Be patient and kind to yourself. You may still be looking for success two or three years after leaving college, but that doesn't mean you've failed."

www.rsc.org.uk

webTitle: How to train effectively for skiing

fields.headline: Peak condition
fields.trailText: Skiing is a technical sport. This may seem obvious, but it means that pure fitness plays a relatively small role in successful skiing. Even at international level, where the ski-racers are finely-tuned athletes spending several hours a day keeping their bodies in the peak of condition, technique must come first.
fields.body:
Skiing is a technical sport. This may seem obvious, but it means that pure fitness plays a relatively small role in successful skiing. Even at international level, where the ski-racers are finely-tuned athletes spending several hours a day keeping their bodies in the peak of condition, technique must come first.

For the holiday skier, the physical demands of skiing will depend upon how hard you want to push yourself. The better your technique, the more efficiently you will ski, and the less physically taxing you will find it to negotiate a particular run with a given level of difficulty. But of course, the more skilful skiers may want to spice things up by taking on the challenge of a harder run, thereby increasing the physical demands on their body.

Unfortunately, it is often too easy for early intermediate skiers of a certain level (usually males) to use their natural strength to compensate for a lack of technique. Muscling your way down the mountain with brute force is all very well in the short term, but the gradual build-up of fatigue will increase the risk of making a mistake and thereby sustaining an injury. High altitude is another factor that puts unaccustomed stress on the body.

So, it is important that fitness is not seen as an alternative to good technique, but as a complement to it; a prerequisite to "pushing the envelope", under the guidance of a good instructor. Only then can you experience the enjoyment that will come from improving enough to maybe even ski a glamorous black run, and survive returning in one piece to brag about it in the bar afterwards!

Here's a simple, 10-week, 10-point programme to help you gain that fitness between now and Christmas. Try to do it three times per week. The suggested number of repetitions are there as a guide, and how many you complete will obviously depend on your level of fitness at any given point. For those with neither the time nor the money to attend a gym, I should point out that none of the exercises require any special equipment, other than a floor and a chair.

1 Cardio-vascular session: When exerting yourself in thin air at high altitude, the most important muscle in your body is the heart. You can train it, and improve your blood's oxygen-carrying capacity, with any steady exercise that keeps your heart rate at a constant level, somewhere between roughly 120 and 160 beats per minute. (If your watch has a second hand, just count your pulse for six seconds and multiply by 10.) You can cycle, run or just walk briskly. Start with a 10-minute session, and increase it by 5 minutes every second week. Even just walking up and down stairs instead of using lifts and escalators will help.

2 Dorsal raises: Lie on your stomach with your arms stretched forwards, and raise hands and feet simultaneously. Or, as a variation, raise your left hand and right foot, then your right hand and left foot. This strengthens your back muscles, which are important "shock absorbers" in skiing, especially in moguls. Start with 10 repetitions and add five every two weeks.

3 Abdominal raises: The stomach muscles are useful in skiing for maintaining good posture, and recovering from any temporary loss of balance. Lie on your back with your knees bent, and slowly curl upwards and forwards to touch your knees. Start with 10 repetitions and add five every two weeks.

4 Knee-bends: Standing upright, just bend in the knees and ankles, not the waist. (Keeping your arms outstretched in front may help.) Only go as far as a 90-deg bend in the knee joint. Start with 15 repetitions and add five every two weeks. More athletic skiers can switch to doing one-legged knee-bends after six weeks.

5 Triceps dips: You use your arms more often than you'd think when skiing; every time you push or support yourself with your poles in a lift queue. From a seated position on a chair, straighten your legs and rest them on the ground as far in front as possible. Then, shuffle forward so that your bottom moves off the front of the chair. Now, bend and straighten your arms. Start with five repetitions, and add five every two weeks.

6 Downhill tuck: Static local muscular endurance is vital for skiing. This exercise is a bit of a "burner", but will acclimatise your quadriceps (thigh muscles) to coping with high amounts of lactic acid. Stand with your feet slightly apart, bend your knees until they're at right angles, then bend at the waist so that your chest is just above your thighs and your elbows are just in front of your knees. Keep your head up, looking forward, to strengthen the neck. Start by holding the position for 20 seconds, and add five extra seconds each week.

7 Sideways hip stretch: Standing with your feet apart and your hands on your hips, gradually bend sideways to the left, leaning further and further over for about 20 seconds. Then repeat to the right. Make sure you're bending in a totally sideways plane.

8 Hamstring stretch: Put your left foot up on a chair, and with both legs straight, bend forward and try to bring your chin towards your left knee. Start gently at first, and increase the stretch gradually over about 20 seconds. Then repeat with the right leg on the chair.

9 Hip flexor/quadriceps stretch: Kneel about a yard behind a chair, holding on to the back of the chair with your outstretched hands. Then bring your left foot forward and place it on the ground directly beneath your hands. If you now push your hips forward, you will feel your right hip flexor (at the very top and front of your thigh) stretching. Increase the stretch gradually over 20 seconds. Then switch legs and repeat the process.

For a slightly different stretch, namely the quadriceps, go through the same initial movements as above. Then reach behind you with your right hand, grab your right foot, and pull it up so it is close to your right buttock. You should also feel this stretching the front of your thigh, but along the whole length of it.

10 Calf stretch: Stand on the lowest step of a staircase, facing up the stairs, and place your left foot so that it is half on/half off the step. Then, gradually push your left heel downwards, while still partially supporting your weight with the right leg. Then switch feet.

More athletic skiers can start to do two circuits of exercises 2-6 after the sixth week. Exercises 7-10 are for flexibility, and can also be done as a warm-up while on your ski holiday.

Always consult your doctor before doing any of these exercises if you suffer from heart or breathing problems, or if you are injured in any way.

If you wish to train more seriously, you should consider joining a gym for proper weight training. (An especially useful machine is the "hamstring curl"; regular skiers have strong quadriceps, and must strengthen their hamstrings in order to maintain a balanced loading of the knee joint.) Always do a full warm-up before any weight training, and a full stretching session afterwards.

Only then can you experience the enjoyment that will come from improving enough to maybe even ski a glamorous black run, and survive returning in one piece to brag about it in the bar afterwards! Here's a simple, 10-week, 10-point programme to help you gain that fitness between now and Christmas. Try to do it three times per week. The suggested number of repetitions are there as a guide, and how many you complete will obviously depend on your level of fitness at any given point. For those with neither the time nor the money to attend a gym, I should point out that none of the exercises require any special equipment, other than a floor and a chair. 1 Cardio-vascular session: When exerting yourself in thin air at high altitude, the most important muscle in your body is the heart. You can train it, and improve your blood's oxygen-carrying capacity, with any steady exercise that keeps your heart rate at a constant level, somewhere between roughly 120 and 160 beats per minute. (If your watch has a second hand, just count your pulse for six seconds and multiply by 10.) You can cycle, run or just walk briskly. Start with a 10-minute session, and increase it by 5 minutes every second week. Even just walking up and down stairs instead of using lifts and escalators will help. 2 Dorsal raises: Lie on your stomach with your arms stretched forwards, and raise hands and feet simultaneously. Or, as a variation, raise your left hand and right foot, then your right hand and left foot. This strengthens your back muscles, which are important "shock absorbers" in skiing, especially in moguls. Start with 10 repetitions and add five every two weeks. 3 Abdominal raises: The stomach muscles are useful in skiing for maintaining good posture, and recovering from any temporary loss of balance. Lie on your back with your knees bent, and slowly curl upwards and forwards to touch your knees. Start with 10 repetitions and add five every two weeks. 4 Knee-bends: Standing upright, just bend in the knees and ankles, not the waist. (Keeping your arms outstretched in front may help.) Only go as far as a 90-deg bend in the knee joint. Start with 15 repetitions and add five every two weeks. More athletic skiers can switch to doing one-legged knee-bends after six weeks. 5 Triceps dips: You use your arms more often than you'd think when skiing; every time you push or support yourself with your poles in a lift queue. From a seated position on a chair, straighten your legs and rest them on the ground as far in front as possible. Then, shuffle forward so that your bottom moves off the front of the chair. Now, bend and straighten your arms. Start with five repetitions, and add five every two weeks. 6 Downhill tuck: Static local muscular endurance is vital for skiing. This exercise is a bit of a "burner", but will acclimatise your quadriceps (thigh muscles) to coping with high amounts of lactic acid. Stand with your feet slightly apart, bend your knees until they're at right angles, then bend at the waist so that your chest is just above your thighs and your elbows are just in front of your knees. Keep your head up, looking forward, to strengthen the neck. Start by holding the position for 20 seconds, and add five extra seconds each week. 7 Sideways hip stretch: Standing with your feet apart and your hands on your hips, gradually bend sideways to the left, leaning further and further over for about 20 seconds. Then repeat to the right. Make sure you're bending in a totally sideways plane. 8 Hamstring stretch: Put your left foot up on a chair, and with both legs straight, bend forward and try to bring your chin towards your left knee. Start gently at first, and increase the stretch gradually over about 20 seconds. Then repeat with the right leg on the chair. 9 Hip flexor/quadriceps stretch: Kneel about a yard behind a chair, holding on to the back of the chair with your outstretched hands. Then bring your left foot forward and place it on the ground directly beneath your hands. If you now push your hips forward, you will feel your right hip flexor (at the very top and front of your thigh) stretching. Increase the stretch gradually over 20 seconds. Then switch legs and repeat the process. For a slightly different stretch, namely the quadriceps, go through the same initial movements as above. Then reach behind you with your right hand, grab your right foot, and pull it up so it is close to your right buttock. You should also feel this stretching the front of your thigh, but along the whole length of it. 10 Calf stretch: Stand on the lowest step of a staircase, facing up the stairs, and place your left foot so that it is half on/half off the step. Then, gradually push your left heel downwards, while still partially supporting your weight with the right leg. Then switch feet. More athletic skiers can start to do two circuits of exercises 2-6 after the sixth week. Exercises 7-10 are for flexibility, and can also be done as a warm-up while on your ski holiday. Always consult your doctor before doing any of these exercises if you suffer from heart or breathing problems, or if you are injured in any way. If you wish to train more seriously, you should consider joining a gym for proper weight training. (An especially useful machine is the "hamstring curl"; regular skiers have strong quadriceps, and must strengthen their hamstrings in order to maintain a balanced loading of the knee joint.) Always do a full warm-up before any weight training, and a full stretching session afterwards.

webTitle: At the end of the world

fields.headline: At the end of the world
fields.standfirst: In the third part of his series on South America,  Hank Wangford  arrives in the frontier town of Ushuaia, gateway to Cape Horn and Antarctica
fields.trailText: In the third part of his series on South America, Hank Wangford arrives in the frontier town of Ushuaia, gateway to Cape Horn and Antarctica.
fields.body:
The names sound gothic - Patagonia, Tierra del Fuego, Land of Fire, the uttermost part of the earth. Disturbingly jagged mountaintops confirm this gothic image, lurching up towards us as the plane tries to settle down to sea level. We are relieved to see the new intercontinental airstrip.

Ushuaia nestles along the shore of a glass-surfaced bay on the Beagle Channel, in the lee of the spiky Martial mountains, which rear up dramatically like a backdrop from Dungeons and Dragons. It was a skyline I knew well from the Uttermost Part of the Earth, an inspiring account of life and hardship with the Indians by Lucas Bridges, son of the missionary Thomas Bridges, who in 1870 effectively founded and built Ushuaia - "the bay penetrating to the west". The jagged ridge of the Five Brothers and the looming witch's hat of Mount Olivia were old friends.

When Darwin passed through here in 1833, he saw the Yamanas, aboriginal shore dwellers living a stark life, half naked and keeping warm with the fires they carried everywhere in their canoes. He thought they were wretched and subhuman. But Thomas Bridges compiled a dictionary of the Yamana language, showing it to be subtle, philosophical and rich in complex imagery. He stopped at 30,000 words, but the Yamana have long since died out from influenza and civilisation.

Ushuaia is the most southerly city in the world. The original mission became Argentina's biggest penal colony where many anarchists were sent down from the north. The prisoners made Ushuaia into a city, building whole streets of houses, bridges and even a 15-mile railway. The writer Bruce Chatwin famously couldn't get in when writing In Patagonia, but times have changed. It is now a museum with tasteful life-size figures of anarchist prisoners lurching out of the cells.

The nearest thing to a cathedral here is a church with a synthesised Casiotone bell instead of real chimes. But you have to remind yourself that this is a frontier town and as such it still has echoes of the gold rush of a century ago. Nowadays it is at the tourist frontier to Cape Horn and Antarctica and the Gothic mountains and glaciers that lie beyond.

Ushuaia runs along a rise on the waterfront. Steep, criss-cross streets move up the hill, like Stanley in the Falklands. Its main street, San Martin, is non-stop shops with no shortage of End of the World and penguin paraphernalia. Downtown Ushuaia is full of cheap whisky; it is a free port and the whole of South America is mad for whisky: bars are called whiskerias; clothes shops have bottles of White Horse wrapped in jeans; newspaper shops with Teacher's poking out among the magazines.

Though meat is the heart of Argentine food with plenty of parrillas, meat barbeques, in Ushuaia, it was the rich pickings from the cold Fuegian waters that called. The centolla, the king crab, is a treat. Sweeter and more delicate than our crab, the best we had was in a Ushuaia restaurant called Kaupe (Roca 470, tel: 2901 422704). In a family home up the hill, Ernesto Vivian, an engineer, decided to cook rather than work for the gas company. He cooked so well, with his wife Tessie serving, that they turned their front room into a restaurant. Ernesto does beautiful centolla salad and sea bass en papillote (wrapped in a parchment or foil package). He wouldn't give me the cheap white wine I chose and insisted on serving his best Rutini.

On the seafront, Volver (Maipu 37, tel: 42901 23977) serves great seafood surrounded by loads of end-of-the-world bric-a-brac. Down the road, Tia Elvira's (Maipu 349, tel: 2901 424725) is like your old auntie's front room. They have yet more delicious seafood - hake, bass, and others too Spanish to mention. It's all good.

This wall-to-wall tourist town has a bewildering number of tour operators offering trips into the mountains or down the Beagle Channel. We took a small boat run by a company called Patagonia Adventure, and it got us right in close to the sea-lion colonies.

Clouds of hot breath shot out as the thick-necked males roared like fire eaters at the tourists and the females basked and looked impressed. A colony of cormorants who shared the rocks added a sharp tang. Out in the open, we twitched at wandering albatrosses, skuas, petrels, Antarctic shearbills, delicate winged terns and flightless steamer ducks neurotically paddling full tilt through the water.

For trekkers, the moun tains are awesome. They are the jagged end of the Andean dragon's tail, tectonic residues jutting 6,000ft into the sky before sinking into the angry southern seas. You can walk to the spectacular Albino Eye, a glacial lagoon high in the mountains, or the nearby Esmeralda Lake, an unearthly milky-green lake deep among the lurching peaks.

The best walk close to town is straight up into the mountains to the Martial glacier, hanging like an apron from a high ridge overlooking the Hebridean blue of the Beagle Channel. On the edge of autumn, the ñire trees had just started to flame in unison with the scarlet flowers of the firebush.

The finest glaciers are up in the Darwin Range. For a price, you can sail up the Beagle Channel sipping whisky with 8,000-year-old ice, watching the glaciers at their dramatic best falling into the sea.

Fireland has spectacular fishing. My local GP in the west of Ireland flies over every year to cast a fly. The idea of an Irishman leaving Connemara (a place that most anglers would give their casting arm to visit) to fish at the other end of the earth seems absurd. But ever since enormous brown trout were introduced into the rivers by Thomas Bridges' grandson, this has some of the finest fishing in the world.

This place is so good for fish that George Bush was here the same time as me, up in a $1,000-a-night 10-star lodge the other side of the mountains. CNN's Ted Turner has just bought an estancia up on the frontier.

You can go horse trekking from Adolfo Imbert's equestrian centre. The best trips involve 10 days of riding, camping and eating meat across the uninhabited eastern end of the island, the rugged Mitre peninsula. It is huge, deserted and bordered by wild, wreck-strewn Atlantic beaches.

We climbed a narrow trail up the side of Mount Susana, down to the seashore, through beech woods, scrambling down into a gully and across some rapids.

As we came round the side of Mount Susana, I saw something I'd never seen before. Locked in mist along the coast of Navarino and Hoste on the southern side of the Channel, against Hoste's baroque skyline of peaks and ridges, was a straight horizontal rainbow stretched out like a spectral staircarpet along the water's edge.

I found a big Croatian presence in Fireland, a whole community having been set up following the large waves of migrants that arrived around the turn of the century, such as the Marusic, Pomenic, Vrsalovic families, some coming out for the gold rush, others as carpenters or butchers.

Over the other side, Porvenir is almost totally Croat. Some say that the wildness of Fireland's mountains was reminiscent of Dalmatia's peaks for all their dessicated whiteness. Many of the original Croatian houses still stand. The well-to-do Beban house, transplanted along the shore, is particularly fine and is a centre for arts and crafts. At night it lights up like an Addams Family theme mansion in Blackpool.

A while back, I'd heard of a cowboy further south on Navarino Island, a man who rears horses and cattle, the grandson of a Croat who left Dalmatia to get as far away as possible from his homeland. Just north of Cape Horn on the windswept edge of the Antarctic sea is as far as itis possible to get. Just think, the most southerly cowboy in the world is a Croat.

The practicals

British Airways (0345 222111) flies to Buenos Aires from £445 return. Hank Wangford flew from Buenos Aires to Ushuaia on a LAPA Discover Argentina Airpass, $339 for three return flights, $100 for each extra leg, details 020-7707 4576. He stayed at the Hotel Las Lengas, Ushuaia (0054 2901 423366, e-mail: laslengas@tierradelfuego.org.ar) $80 single $100 double. For hotels, tours and bookings, contact the Secretaria de Turismo, San Martin 674, Ushuaia, tel: 0054 2901 432000, e-mail: muniush @tierradelfuego.org.ar. For general tourist information, call the Argentine consulate in London: 020-7318 1340. Recommended reading: Uttermost Part of the Earth by Lucas Bridges (out of print), In Patagonia by Bruce Chatwin (Penguin, £7.99).

webTitle: Rural England  finds a guardian angel

fields.headline: Rural England  finds a guardian angel
fields.standfirst: Campaigners fighting for the preservation of the countryside have hailed environment secretary John Prescott's move to curb the building of new houses
fields.trailText: The government this week took another step back in its plans to authorise hundreds of thousands of new homes amid intense pressure by countryside campaigners.
fields.body:
The government this week took another step back in its plans to authorise hundreds of thousands of new homes amid intense pressure by countryside campaigners.

It delighted the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE) by announcing that the number of extra new homes needed in the north-east will be much lower than it originally indicated.

A panel of independent experts, appointed by the government to scrutinise local authority development plans, has taken a cautious approach, in effect saying the region must wait and see if regeneration works before hugely increasing the number of homes. The panel also wants more effort made to stem the outflow of Geordies from the region.

The publication of draft regional planning guidance for the north-east was welcomed by the CPRE, which called for the earlier targets for new homes in the area to be lowered.

In the original regional planning guidance, councils and other agencies identified a need for another 119,000 new dwellings over the next 20 years to cater for the predicted population growth. But the panel was unconvinced by planners' arguments. Even though there are more owner-occupiers in the north-east than 20 years ago the region still suffers from the decline in manufacturing industries and has large pockets of unemployment. Instead, the panel said an additional 110,000 dwellings would be needed between 1996 and 2016.

Around the country independent panels are examining draft planning guidance for each of England's regions, paying close attention to regional targets for new homes. After a public hearing the panel's recommendations are passed to the environment secretary John Prescott for his approval.

In the south-east, the publication of the panel's recommendations caused an uproar when it called for 1.1m homes over the next 20 years to allow the economy to prosper. Mr Prescott attempted to soothe countryside campaigners and councils in March with a draft response containing more modest targets. He rejected the panel's recommendations, instead plumping for 860,000 homes.

The new figure was still more than the 660,000 homes proposed by Serplan, which represents councils and other parties with an interest in planning for the south-east. Mr Prescott tried to quell dissent by insisting the new homes would need to be built on the same "footprint" as the 660,000. In practice this means developments should be higher density and more akin to the terraces that characterised Georgian and Victorian London than the sprawl associated with Brookside Close and modern suburbia. As further evidence of the government's commitment to regenerating cities, 60% of the new homes would be built on recycled or "brownfield" land, he said.

By the summer, it was the turn of the south-west to come under the microscope. Here planning inspectors also caused a storm when their report concluded that building the equivalent of 10 cities the size of Exeter, some 407,000 new homes, was necessary over the next 20 years. In this instance the panel wanted 40,000 more than the councils in the area said should be built.

Nic Best of the CPRE's north-eastern region says there are deep contradictions within the process for reviewing new house building plans. "Each of the regional planning panels is setting up housing targets without relating it to other regions," he says. "The south-east wants to build houses for the people it expects want to come and live there in future. But the north-east panel wants homes for people it ex pects to stay put," he explains.

The developers and councils argue that building is needed to support regeneration. A larger stock of good quality housing is needed to entice people to an area.

But Mr Best says it is not that simple. CPRE is not against regeneration: "After all, it's more sustainable if people live near where they work. But we want to see if the number of people leaving the north-east eases off, if the regeneration plans work and migration falls before we build too many new homes," he says.

Meanwhile, Mr Prescott's ministry, the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, has introduced safeguards to protect the countryside from urban sprawl. All plans for developments of 150 homes or more on greenfield sites must now come before Mr Prescott before local authorities can give them the go-ahead.

The move means developments who do not abide by new rules on density and type of land used can be stopped in their tracks. Ministers want to ensure that all developments, even those that have been in the pipeline for some time, reflect latest government thinking on planning.

The circular will convince councils and developers that the secretary of state means business on protecting the countryside, says Julie Stainton, planning officer for CPRE. "Even if they have already allocated a site for development they must review it. They can't say they have a plan and will stick with it until it expires," she says.

The Housebuilders' Federation says developers are doing their bit to protect the countryside. Spokesman Pierre Williams says that the industry has almost reached the government's target of 60% of development on recycled land. "The industry is building 58% of homes on brownfield sites. The largest builders such as Barratt are managing 70%." Mr Williams says the industry needs more financial incentives to develop sites previously used for another purpose. "More funding is needed to make unviable brownfield sites worth taking on. Builders won't take on sites that cost more to develop than they can earn in sales."

The housebuilders say that some local authorities are us ing the new emphasis on using recycled land to stop all development, an approach they condemn as short-sighted and disastrous for the economy. "If the cities are seen to decline people will want to move out to find a better quality of life. There will always be demand for a certain amount of greenfield land to meet this need."

webTitle: Roger Bray selects his favourite skiing resorts

fields.headline: A run for your money
fields.standfirst: Around 750,000 of us will go skiing or boarding this year.  Roger Bray selects 10 of his favourite resorts
fields.trailText: Doing the sites: Around 750,000 of us will go skiing or boarding this year. Roger Bray selects 10 of his favourite resorts
fields.body:
1 Val d'Isère/Tignes, France
There are drawbacks to the place, admittedly. Among them are the uncomfortably large number of other British skiers, long queues for the main access lifts at the start of the day and for some connections at the end of the afternoon. But such is the enormous variety of skiing, to which few other areas can hold a candle, that these seem minor irritations.

It has been argued that, depending on one's level of ability, the slopes are all too easy or too difficult, with not enough confidence builders in between for intermediate skiers. Certainly, once you take out the easy green runs, most pistes are a degree or two steeper than those of most resorts. The accomplished skier, however, will find it impossible to exhaust all the options in a week, or perhaps even a fortnight.

Tignes is tarting itself up but its architecture is too bleakly functional for it ever to be considered pretty. Val sprawls a bit but has better looks and, with haunts such as the celebrated Dick's Tea Bar, is reckoned to offer the livelier night life.

2 Méribel, France
Any resort in the Trois Vallées would do. Some would go for the sophistication of Courchevel, some for the altitude of Val Thorens - the highest in Europe. But Méribel is arguably the most convenient base from which to roam this vast expanse of ski terrain in the French Savoie.

Founded by an Englishman just before the second world war, it has a preponderance of chalets, is somewhat spread out - and also attracts a disproportionately large British clientele. But the skiing compensates. If the Trois Vallées finished behind Val d'Isère/ Tignes in a vote for the world's finest slopes I'm sure thousands of skiers would be screaming for a recount.

The area has 200 lifts and some 375 miles of prepared pistes, but that ignores the many off-piste options.

An intermediate can ski for mile upon mile of exercising but unfrightening terrain but there is no shortage of challenges for experts, not least the couloirs (corridors) from Saulire. Some linking runs are very busy and can be unpleasant, but it is always possible to escape the crowds and find some uncluttered snow.

3 St Anton, Austria
The most impressive skiing in the country. Some runs marked easy blue would rate a trickier red anywhere else, some reds would be black, and its marked, unpisted itineraries and other off-piste options are rarely found in Europe outside the major areas in France.

In spring conditions, with a guide who knows where and when the snow will be best, St Anton can set the pulse racing. Yet despite its tough reputation, it is a good option for families with young children because it is always easy on the Valluga side of the valley to ski hard and get back quickly to the nursery slopes.

The resort is undergoing a makeover. Generations of skiers have plodded from their hotels to the slopes beneath the railway line which crosses the Arlberg pass but now the track has been diverted to the outskirts. A new gondola lift is being built which could see the demolition of the ageing Kandaharbahn mountain railway.

4 Zermatt, Switzerland
So infuriatingly inconvenient that it ought not to qualify - yet its unique character keeps it among the elite. Perhaps it is the image of families arriving at hotels for Christmas in horse-drawn sleighs for Christmas, swathed in fur and laden with gifts. Or maybe it is the plethora of great eateries on and off the slopes, or champagne at Elsie's Place, or hotels such as the Monte Rosa, where Winston Churchill stayed and which Edward Whymper used as a base when he set out to climb Zermatt's trademark, the Matterhorn.

There are plenty of pluses to make up for the irritation of lift queues and clumping around icy streets in ski boots - and you can avoid that by staying at the new Riffelalp Hotel up on the slopes.

The skiing, by the way, is excellent, particularly for intermediates and above, but Zermatt is definitely for those who want more than just a work out on the snow.

5 Taos, New Mexico
Like no other. You can ski all day on perfect snow and drop down to a balmy Rio Grande valley for an outdoor swim among the cacti and sagebrush.

The skiing is sensational. When you arrive the first thing you see is Al's Run, named after a doctor who skied it with an oxygen tank after suffering a heart attack. It is so daunting that the management was prompted to post a notice, reassuring the apprehensive that there is easier terrain, too. And so there is, but it is for the steep and bumpy that you remember this mountain.

And at night there is always the town of Taos, still a magnet for writers and artists, where Georgia O'Keefe painted and DH Lawrence came hoping the dry air would alleviate his tuberculosis.

6 Aspen, Colorado
Great skiing, smart hotels, splendid restaurants and shopping - Aspen has it all. With neighbouring Aspen Highlands, Snowmass and Buttermilk all on the same lift ticket, the choice of terrain is enormous. Aspen's Ajax mountain has bump slopes to tax the most rubber-legged. For powderhounds, there is wonderful snowcat skiing in back-country glades. Snowmass has the Big Burn, acknowledged among the longest, widest, most ecstatically enjoyable intermediate runs anywhere. Highlands skiing is rich and varied, while Buttermilk is ideal for beginners and children.

Clear your credit card account before you go - but although it has a ritzy image and some unashamedly expensive hotels, Aspen has plenty of more modestly-priced options. As for celebs, it is big enough to swallow them.

7 Jackson Hole, Wyoming
It is unlikely you will leave without sighting moose. To arrive on a day of bright sunshine and spot one of those ungainly creatures drinking from the glittering, snow banked Snake River, droplets shaking from its disproportionately huge head, leaves an unfading imprint. Skiing back to a condominium, I once encountered a pair of them, grazing on shoots a few yards from the trail.

Yet it is for elk that Jackson Hole is best known. The refuge here, established to feed them through the harsh winters, was one of the world's first major conservation projects.

Its reputation as a resort for hard skiers is justified by some unnervingly tricky descents. Skiing the Hobacks on a day of leaden skies and fresh powder is hard to beat. And, as in Val d'Isère and St Anton, its intermediate skiing provides a consistent challenge. That need not deter those with more modest talents, for there is plenty of easier terrain. Besides, its greatest draws are the remoteness of that broad, flat valley on the edge of Yellowstone National Park.

8 Les Arcs, France
Varied is the best way to describe the piste lay out at this purpose-built French resort, which has something for skiers of all standards. Off piste, it can be wonderful, too.

Always innovative, this was the resort which introduced ski évolutif - a method of teaching that involves starting on very short skis and gradually progressing to longer ones - and still offers customers the chance to test their courage on the "Flying Kilometre" speed-skiing course, where even first timers can top 85mph.

Most visitors stay in apartments, and Les Arcs is not famous for its nightlife, but the sheer convenience of stepping straight from your accommodation on to such excellent slopes is an undeniable bonus.

9 Whistler/Blackcomb, British Columbia
Purists may argue that its nearness to the Pacific sometimes compromises conditions, but even if it is sugary at the bottom the snow is invariably good at the top. Proximity to Vancouver, less than two hours' drive away, certainly means queues and sometimes crowded runs at weekends. But the all-round experience keeps the merged resorts of Whistler and Blackcomb in the premier league.

Though their neighbouring mountains are cheek by jowl, you have to return to the bottom to switch between them. However the ski area is vast and full of surprises, boasting long, swooping intermediate confidence builders and tough bowls and couloirs for experts.

10 Verbier, Switzerland
There has never been any question mark against the quality and breadth of Verbier's skiing. Those who know it intimately swear by it. More than 250 miles of marked runs cover four valleys, linking the resort with Thyon, Nendaz and Veysonnaz. A huge network of expert descents provides constant challenge and variety.

Verbier classifies almost all its black runs as "ski itineraries" which, while they may not be groomed, are skied by such an army of aficionados that they might as well be. They include the notorious and often heavily mogulled Tortin. On top of that, genuine off-piste possibilities are legion. Nor could anyone complain of a lack of restaurants or rocking night spots.

Despite all this, however, Verbier was attacked in the 1980s for failure to update lifts which led to long queues. That has changed. Two new gondolas have been built and an electronic, hands-free lift pass introduced. Improvement has been dramatic.

fields.trailText: Feeling fruity
fields.body:
Feeling fruity

Celebrate the English apple with apple bowling and bobbing, apple identification tables, cookery demonstrations and a longest peel competition.

October 15, 11am-5.30pm. £2/£1/£5. Acorn Bank, Temple Sowerby, Penrith, Cumbria (017683 61893).

Puppets in pop

Flat Eric, Blur's dancing milk carton, Supergrass's Pumping on Your Stereo rubber puppets and masks from Fatboy Slim's Right Here, Right Now are all part of the UK's first multimedia exhibition of animated icons from popular culture.

Until October 29. Mon-Sat 10am-5pm until Oct 18. Oct 19-29 daily 10am-9pm. Free. The University of Brighton Gallery, Grand Parade (01273 644099).

A piece of history

The largest regular antiques fair in the world takes place this week with over 4,000 stands selling wares from £5 to £50,000.

October 16/17. Mon 5.30am-7pm. Tues 7-4pm. Mon £20/Tues £5. Newark International Antiques Fair, The Newark and Nottinghamshire Showground, Newark (01636 702 326).

You must be joking

This year's line up for the Aberdeen Alternative Festival includes comedians Lee Hurst and Mark Little and music from Kid Creole & The Coconuts and Shine pianist David Helfgott.

Until October 21. Information: 01224 635 822.

Fight to the finish

The bloody fight for Senlac Hill is recreated this weekend on the anniversary of the Battle of Hastings, when more than 1,000 Norman and Saxon warriors will relive the struggle on the actual battlefield where the confrontation took place.

October 14/15,10am-5pm. £8/£4. Battle Abbey, Battle, East Sussex (01424 773 792).

Rather crafty

Innovative designs are always a feature of the Chelsea Crafts Fair, where exhibitors change weekly.

October 17-29. Open Tues-Fri 10am-8pm, Sat/Sun to 6pm. Closed Oct 23 for changeover. £7 one week, £10 two. Chelsea Old Town Hall, King's Road, London SW3 (no phone).

Paws for thought

Watch gundogs being put through their paces at Audley End House this Sunday in a series of doghandling demonstrations, including training displays where children can join in.

October 15, £4.50/£2.50. Audley End House, nr Saffron Walden, Cambs (01799 522399).

Spinning a yarn

Sitting comfortably? Then the weekend of tales can begin, from a master story-teller with more than 400 yarns up his sleeve.

Sat/Sun. £3.50/£1.80. Dartmouth Castle, Dartmouth, Devon (01803 833588).

webTitle: Peter Ratcliffe: Swiss army knife | World receiver radio | Rosary beads

fields.headline: Peter Ratcliffe never travels without...
fields.trailText: Swiss army knife | World receiver radio | Rosary beads
fields.body:
A necessity: A Swiss army knife. It has everything - hacksaw, blade, scissors and, most importantly when you are on holiday, a corkscrew. Most guys in the SAS carry one. You can use it for mending your rifle, map-reading, basically everything.

A luxury: A world receiver radio for listening to the sport on Saturdays. I also like to keep up with the news.

A good luck charm: A set of rosary beads which was given to me by a very old lady in 1970. They got her husband through the first world war and her son through the second. I kept them in the breast pocket of my uniform or in my wallet when in civilian clothes.

If only: A mobile laundry unit for the jungle or some way of not having to get into a wet, stinking uniform in the morning.

webTitle: Realm of the senses

fields.headline: Realm of the senses
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi finds the sights and smells of the city founded by the Berbers impossible to resist
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi finds the sights and smells of the city founded by the Berbers impossible to resist.
fields.body:
Marrakech's bewilderingly seductive Djemaa el Fna square has left a powerful impression on visiting writers. These range from Elias Canetti and Paul Bowles - who said, without it, Marrakech could be any Moroccan city - to Esther Freudin her novel turned film, Hideous Kinky.

But perhaps the most telling word comes from one still living in the medina, Juan Goytisolo - known to the locals as "the Spaniard". Hymning the transient life of Djemaa el Fna in his novel Makbara (Serpent's Tail), he scoffs at the contradictory advice fed to tourists; namely to approach in daylight or after nightfall, by stealthy observation from its café terraces or through a headlong plunge into its perpetual commotion. "All the guidebooks lie," he writes. "There is simply no way of getting a firm grip on it."

Less a square than an irregular expanse, abutted by souks and spectacularly backed by the high Atlas mountains, Djemaa el Fna may have been named "assembly of the dead" as a place of execution, or "mosque of nothing" after an abandoned building plan. But it now draws Marrakchis and strangers alike in a perpetual round of trading, eating and entertainment.

Partly for its protean elusiveness, Djemaa el Fna is a compelling spectacle, with a sensory overload of cooking smells and stove smoke, car horns and mesmeric drum beats. Musicians, snake-charmers, acrobats, healers and henna painters compete to beguile onlookers.

The culture of the city, founded in the 11th century as a Berber hub, reflects its Arab-African origins, as Berbers mingled with Arabs, Saharan nomads and gnaoua - descendants of sub-Saharan slaves who produce the drumming trance music of the square. While Muslim women in the casbah may still wear the all-enveloping burka, younger ones are to be seen astride mopeds in sleeveless blouses and see-through gauze.

What to see

Marrakech divides broadly into the still vibrant medina, rebuilt under the French protectorate of 1912-56, and the new town of Gueliz. The city walls - made of tabia, the red mud of the plains mixed with lime - can be traced in a calèche, or pony trap, as part of a two-hour tour (roughly £16). This takes in the palmery, the oasis on which the Berber city was founded,and where stunning sunsets can be enjoyed.

The 12th-century Koutoubia mosque, just west of Djemaa el Fna, is a towering city landmark deemed the finest Islamic monument in north Africa.

Little remains of the city's founding Almoravid dynasty apart from the ruins of a palace beside the Koutoubia. But to the north of the square, amid the labyrinth of souks, is the Ben Yusuf medersa, or koranic school, which was largely rebuilt during the 16th- to 17th-century, again with Andalucian influence. (Open 8.30am-noon, 2.30om-6.30pm; 60p).

South of Djemaa el Fna, palaces nestle beside the Mellah, literally "salt market" and once the largest Jewish ghetto in Morocco. It thrived after the 15th-century expulsions from Catholic Spain, but most of the Jewish population left for Casablanca in the last century or emigrated. The quarter remains a place of trade, in everything from TVs to rosewater.

The Saadian El Badi palace, meaning "the incomparable", is also in ruins, but worth seeing for its grandiose scale. (Open 8.30am-noon, 2.30pm-6.30pm; 60p, plus about 60p tip for the guide.) Nearby are the lavishly decorated Saadian tombs (same hours and entrance fee). Rediscovered in 1917 and restored under French rule, they have separate men's and women's rooms, and zellij (intricate tiles) on tombs in the open cemetery - they all face east to Mecca, but are occupied by Marrakchi Jews.

It is worth a walk through the adjoining casbah, where men sometimes sit outside sewing djellabas (hooded outer garment), while mosharabi , window screens above the doors, allow women to check visitors without being seen. The ubiquitous hand motif on door knockers guards against the evil eye.

Back across the Mellah is the late 19th-century Bahia palace, which houses the king's retinue on his visits to the city. (Open - unless the king is in town - 8.30am-11.45am and 2.30pm-5.45pm; 60p.)

Shaded gardens across the city offer relief from the dry heat. The Menara in the south, less a garden than an olive grove for picnickers, has a tranquil reservoir around which Marrakchis gather with ice creams. Most captivating is the Jardin Majorelle, north of Gueliz, now owned by Yves Saint Laurent. (Open winter 8am-noon, 2pm-5pm; summer 8am-noon, 3pm-7pm;60p.) Bamboo, palms and giant cacti flourish alongside a lily pond with goldfish, and the cool green is offset by walls and tiles paintedroyal blue. The small Museum of Islamic Arts (60p) is also worth a glimpse.

The souks

Anyone serious about buying a carpet or kilim would do well to get their bearings at La Maison du Tapis (7 Derb Baissi, Kasbah), a government co-op where fixed prices mean you can accept a mint tea without undue pressure to buy.

Few leave without some ceramics - brightly coloured from Safi, or more subdued from Fes. There is also silverwear, leather, brass and copper, and instruments heard in the square, such as tambourines and drums.

Out of town

The Atlantic fishing port of Essaouira is more than three hours away by bus, but under two by long-distance grand-taxi or in a tour minibus. Founded by the Romans and colonised by the Portuguese in the 17th century, it is a beautiful Moorish-Portuguese harbour town, with a wall of cannons pointing to the sea. There is also a thriving artists' quarter (galleries include the Gallerie Frederic Damgaard, Avenue Oqba Ibn Nafiaa) and thuya wood artisans galore. Afalkay Art (9 Place My Hassan) is one of several wooden craft shops with fixed prices.

Try freshly caught grilled fish in the harbour, or take a table overlooking the sea at Le Chalet de La Plage (Boulevard Mohammed V, tel: 475972), for a banquet of oysters (12 for£8) and sardines garnished with coriander (£2.50) - which bear no resemblance to the sad minnows in tins.

The Ourika valley, a summer haven for better-off Marrakchis, though prone to lethal flash floods, is a grand-taxi ride south past clay-red Berber villages camouflaged amid the foothills. You can stop at Berber markets on Monday and Thursday for a glimpse of local life, and there is a Berber Museum en route which is more a shop for artefacts. A stylish stop for lunch with a view is the Hotel Restaurant Ramuntcha (Vallée de L'Ourika, Aghbalou, tel: 114373).

The practicals

Travelscene (020-8427 8800 www.travelscene.co.uk) organises weekend breaks in Marrakech for £408pp (based on two adults sharing) including return GB Airways flights from London Gatwick and two nights' B&B at the five-star Imperial Borj Hotel. (Prices based on travel between Jan 1 and Feb 16 2001. Three nights start from £447pp for the same period.) British Airways (0845 773 3377, www.british airways.co.uk) flies to Marrakech from £330.40 return inclu taxes.

webTitle: ...for later

fields.headline: ...for later
fields.standfirst: Europe I North America I Australasia I Asia
fields.trailText: Europe
fields.body:
Europe

Britain: Enjoy some festive fun in Devon. Guests at the Woodbury Park Hotel, Golf & Country Club can play the 18-hole Oaks course or take a dip in the indoor pool or relax in the sauna. Two nights' from December 24 costs from £130pp, including one lunch, two dinners, all golf and a miniature stocking. Woodbury Park 01395 233 382.

France: Christmas on the French Riviera. The hotel Gray d'Albion, between Croisette and the rue d'Antibes, is offereing two-night breaks over Christmas for £142. Contact Melissa on 0033 4 92 99 79 89 for more information and reservations.

Andorra: Soldeu El Tarter promises fun on and off piste for skiers of all abilities. Evening activities include helicopter flights and torchlit mountain descents. A seven-night package, with accommodation ranging from two- to four-star and return flights from Gatwick between January 7 and January 28, starts from £329. Pavilion Tours 0870 241 0427.

Austria: The most prestigious event in Vienna's winter musical calendar, the Opera Ball, can be experienced between February 21-25 on a four-night package that includes return flights from Heathrow. Prices from £885. Austria Travel 01708 222000.

Italy: A 14-day tour by rail to Italy visits the cities of Florence and Venice and offers the chance to admire the countryside of Chianti and take a boat-trip to the island of Elba. The tours between late April and October next year, begin with Eurostar between London and Paris followed by an overnight sleeper to Florence. Price per person is £1,690 with an additional charge of £990 if you choose to return on the Orient Express. Great Rail Journeys 01904 521900.

North America

Florida: Family villas in the Kissimmee area, with a wealth of nearby theme parks and attractions, available in a seven-night package during January, February and March from Florida Vacations (01727 841568), prices starting from £495.

Australasia

Australia: Two-week packages over the Christmas period from Austravel (0117 933 0450 www.austravel.com) include sightseeing tours of Sydney, Ayers Rock and the Great Barrier Reef. The price of £1,399 includes return flights from Heathrow, domestic flights and is based on two people sharing.

Asia

China: Magic of the Orient is offering a 10-night package, initially based in Shanghai, including a five-day cruise along the Yangtze river. The tour, with departures between March 1 and April 4, costs £1,298 based on twin share and including return Virgin Atlantic flights and transfers. Magic of the Orient (01293 537700 www.magic-of-the-orient.com).

webTitle: All around the Wrekin

fields.headline: All around the Wrekin
fields.standfirst: Roly Smith admires the toast of Shropshire that has long been the source of tall stories
fields.trailText: Roly Smith admires the toast of Shropshire that has long been the source of tall stories.
fields.body:
Midland walkers and climbers speeding west past Telford on the M54 towards Snowdonia always look out for the shaggy, wooded slopes of the Wrekin, towering away to the south.

But this modest 1,335ft (407m) summit is usually ignored by those seeking the greater heights and challenges provided by Welsh rock - it has become merely a gigantic milestone on the road to Wales. But by dismissing it so easily, those summit-baggers are missing one of the finest viewpoints not just in the Midlands, but in the whole of Britain.

Vincent Waite, author of Shropshire Hill Country, was of the opinion that if you climb no other hill in Shropshire, you must climb the Wrekin. Local writer HW Timperley agreed, reckoning that to the people of Shropshire, the Wrekin was "as much a spirit as a hill", and "when you go to it, the underlying mood or feeling is that of a pilgrimage".

The Wrekin is both the symbol and the icon of the county, in much the same way that the rock formation of the Old Man of the Mountains has become New Hampshire's. If Shropshire had the honour of its own coin, as the New England state recently received, the Wrekin would have to be on it. "To all friends round the Wrekin" is still the rousing toast heard among Shropshire folk, and it remains the nostalgic symbol of home for all exiled Salopians.

The reason for all this affection for what is, after all, not even the highest summit in this beautiful Border county, is that the Wrekin, which always proudly and significantly carries the definite article, is undoubtedly a hill with a presence. It rises so sharply and unexpectedly from the pastoral Severn Plain that it forces you to notice it.

There are few mountains in Britain, let alone hills, that have exerted the same powerful influence or sense of place on its surrounding communities. Perhaps Glastonbury Tor, towering over the willow-dotted Somerset Levels, is the nearest parallel.

Geologically speaking, the Wrekin is formed of some of the oldest rocks in Britain, and indeed the world. The lovely, purple-pink and green pastel shades of the Wrekin's Cambrian and Pre-Cambrian rocks go back to the very dawn of the planet, perhaps as much as 2bn years. In the case of the fossil-free Pre-Cambrian, that is before evidence of life itself.

The Wrekin takes its name from the British name of the Roman town of Wroxeter, known to the Romans as Viroconium, whose impressive remains lie about five miles to the west. The British people living near here were known as the Wrocensaetan, or the people of the Wrekin, and the earthworks surrounding its airy summit enclose a 20-acre hill fort dating from the Iron Age. You can imagine the Wrocensaetan watching in wonder as the Romans constructed their ruler-straight imperial highway of Watling Street (now the A5) across the lowlands beneath.

You expect a hill like the Wrekin to attract its fair share of legends, and you're not disappointed. Perhaps the most popular folk story of its origin involves a wicked Welsh giant (or, in some versions, the Devil) who had a grudge against the people of the county town of Shrewsbury. He set off with a great load of earth with which he intended to dam the River Severn and so flood the town and drown all its inhabitants.

On his way, he met a cobbler carrying over his shoulder a sackful of boots to repair, and he asked him directions to Shrewsbury. The cobbler, realising the giant's evil intention, claimed that he'd just walked from Shrewsbury himself, and had worn out his entire load of boots in so doing. The giant groaned in despair and dumped his load of earth where he stood to form the Wrekin.

Another legend tells of two warring giants who were building the Wrekin from soil they had dug from the bed of the Severn. They quarrelled and one killed the other, burying him under the northern outlier of Ercall Hill from whence, it is said, he can still be heard groaning at the dead of night.

We start our ascent of the Wrekin in the shadow of Ercall Hill, where there is limited lay-by parking at Forest Glen or in the disused quarry on Ercall Lane. Walk south along the lane that links Cluddley and Little Wenlock for about a mile until you see a stile on the right leading by the side of Wenlock Wood towards the wooded eastern slopes of the Wrekin.

The woodland path crosses a farm track and eventually you reach a broad forest track which is followed left for about half a mile through avenues of stately beeches around the base of the hill. At a junction of paths at Little Hill, marked by a prominent yew tree, turn right and embark upon the steep climb through the trees directly up the south-western spur of the Wrekin.

You will soon emerge from the trees on the broad, stony track formed by those ancient rocks; then head for the obvious rocky outcrop known as the Needle's Eye. Legend has it that this cleft in the rocks was caused when one of those fighting giants threw his spade into the ground. There is a direct route from Eaton Constantine to the summit through this narrow slit, but it is only for the experienced scrambler.

You feel like you are on the roof of the Midlands, and the 360-degree view from the summit of the Wrekin, complete with circular toposcope, is breathtaking, said to take in no less than 17 counties. In clear conditions, you should be able to make out the blue outline of the Malvern Hills 40 miles to the south; the neighbouring Shropshire summits of the Clee Hills, wooded Wenlock Edge and the long whaleback of the Long Mynd, fronted by the shark's tooth of Caer Caradoc to the south west; and the misty shapes of the Berwyns, the first hills of Wales, filling the western horizon 30 miles away. Nearer at hand, due south, are the smoking cooling towers and chimney at Buildwas, which stand at the entrance to the Severn Gorge; Coalbrookdale and Iron Bridge, birthplaces of the Industrial Revolution, are just downstream.

The well-trodden track now leads gradually down towards the northern end of the hill, passing a radio mast and through first Heaven's Gate and then Hell's Gate, which mark the entrances to the Iron Age hillfort that rings the summit. Significantly perhaps, it is Heaven's Gate which is the narrower.

Dropping down off the hill, you descend through the trees of AE Housman's "forest-fleeced" Wrekin, past a cottage to return to Ercall Lane. Follow this back to the start near the small reservoir at the foot of Lawrence Hill, the third of the named Wrekin foothills.

The practicals

The Wrekin lies about five miles west of Telford, on the minor road between Cluddley and Little Wenlock. The walk is about five miles (8km), easy woodland walking, followed by a stiffish climb to the summit. Allow about three hours. The best map is Ordnance Survey 1:50,000 Landranger sheet 127: Stafford and Telford. Recommended pub: The Huntsman in Little Wenlock. For accommodation and other information, contact The Wrekin and Ironbridge Tourist information Centre, The Wharfage, Ironbridge (01952 432166, www.go2.co.uk/wrekintourism).

webTitle: 'Undiscovered' resorts

fields.headline: What's new in the brochures
fields.trailText: The emergence this year of unfamiliar names such as Brian Head and Beitostolen is evidence of the ski industry's unceasing search for "undiscovered" resorts.
fields.body:
The emergence this year of unfamiliar names such as Brian Head and Beitostolen is evidence of the ski industry's unceasing search for "undiscovered" resorts.

Brian Head, which makes its debut in Virgin's brochure, is in southern Utah, some four hours' drive from the cluster of resorts - among them Park City and Snowbird - in the Wasatch Mountains outside Salt Lake City.

All but 20% of its marked trails are graded "easy to intermediate", although there is a snow cat service to some challenging powder bowls and gullies on Brian Head Park. A potential disadvantage is that the base area, at 9,600ft, is the highest in the state, so going straight there from sea level could leave you short of breath and sleep. A major plus-point in good weather is that you could take time out to visit the astonishing, amphitheatre of translucent stone spires at Bryce Canyon National Park, an hour away by car.

Offering holidays to little-known American destinations may look a mite optimistic in a year when the pound has suffered against the dollar, but Brian Head is not the only unfamiliar name in Virgin's programme. There are three in California - Mount Rose, which is near Reno, Big Bear and Snow Summit. It is even offering trips to the Las Vegas Ski and Snowboard Resort at Lee Canyon, about 45 minutes from the city. Its base is only around 1,000ft lower than Brian Head's, though the skiing there looks somewhat limited.

Montana's Big Mountain has made it into a second brochure. Inghams pioneered it, suggesting that customers combine it with Fernie, a couple of hours north across the border in Canada's British Columbia. Now Edinburgh-based Ski Independence has launched packages there, too. It has fine runs for all standards, and some of the cheapest snowcat skiing anywhere (latest available price if there are four or more on the cat is $45 a head for four hours of sublime powder in the trees).

The magnificent Fernie, which has some of Canada's finest skiing, is rapidly moving from bit part player to centre stage. Crystal is going there for the first time, with one-week self-catering deals starting at £445. The firm has also introduced its charming neighbour, Kimberley.

Inghams offers an interesting fresh option in eastern Canada, where you can stay downtown in Quebec City and ski any of three areas - Mont Sainte Anne, Stoneham or Le Massif. None of these is huge by European standardsn but a week at Quebec's imposing Chateau Frontenac, set high above the St Lawrence River, looks good value at a starting price of £419.

Elsewhere, Club Med opens its second Colorado village this winter. Already well established at Copper Mountain, it has now added a new 261-room complex at the foot of the slopes of Colorado's Crested Butte. Adult one-week prices start at £679.

In Europe, there are signs of a quiet revolution in self catering. Skiers, particularly those who have stayed in large North American condominiums, have become disenchanted with the basic, cramped, egg-box apartments, that are the norm in French purpose-built resorts.

One of these, La Plagne, is trying to enlarge some of its older units. Meanwhile, new standards are being set by MGM Résidences, which opens complexes this season there and in Chamonix. The cost for each of four people sharing a two-bedroom unit, booking through MGM Résidences' British representative, Erna Low, is from £177 a head, including ferry crossings.

Driving to the Alps, while not quite as popular as some industry optimists claim, is slowly attracting more devotees. Witness the fact that Eurotunnel Motoring Holidays has launched its first programme of ski packages to France - and that self-drive specialist Motours has increased choice in its programme by no fewer than 17 French resorts, including Les Carroz, which is linked to the excellent skiing of Flaine.

Skiing with young children can be frustrating. After a few holidays, they may be able to ski black runs - but short skis make it hard to keep up with adults in a schuss. But there are operators who will provide someone else to stretch those who have started at an early age. Family specialist Ski Esprit will arrange advanced classes in Courchevel and La Rosière for 7-12 year olds, starting at £100 for five mornings.

And at Les Gets, in the enormous Portes du Soleil area on the Franco-Swiss border, Ski Famille will provide a qualified British instructor to take confident kids on "safari". Children need to be at least eight, have skied for four weeks, or demonstrate real ability to handle most pistes. The price is £50 for five three-hour morning sessions.

Beitostolen is in Norway, and Thomson Holidays recommends it for families, beginners and low intermediates. Thomson will use new direct charters from Gatwick to Fagernes, about 1hr 30mins from the resort. Customers of Neilson and Crystal will travel on the same flights to Hemsedal, only 45 minutes from the airport.

webTitle: Finding a good place to learn to surf

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Jane Spencer wants to know of a good place where she can learn to surf in February or March.
fields.body:
Jane Spencer wanted to know a good place where she could learn to surf in February/March.

 One of the best spots with good weather, warm water and consistent waves, and within four hours' flying time of the UK is Lanzarote, in the Canary Isles. Contact Surf School Lanzarote - 0034 928 528623. Further afield, Australia is a good bet with surf schools all over the place, and it's summer there in Feb/March as well, while if you want to learn in the chill of British waters the British Surfing Association (01736 360250, e-mail colin@britsurf.demon.co.uk) has details of approved surf schools open year-round in this country.

Alternatively check out my book, Surfing - A Beginner's Manual (published by Fernhurst Books, £11.95).

Alf Alderson
Editor, Surf magazine

 Puerto Escondido, Oaxaca, Mexico is great for surfing at that time of the year and there are various places in the town to learn. Puerto Angel, on the same coast is also good.

Neil Paterson

 Oleron Island off the West coast of France has an excellent surf school which is open all year round. Contact Diabolo Fun, Surf Wind School, BP l 17650 St Denis d'Oleron. e-mail didier_lafitte@wanadoo.fr. The weather is very good even in February.

Margaret Duffy

I'm planning to take a year off and cycle round the world on the cheap, and I was wondering how much I should budget for on a daily basis? Andrea Crisp
